DIVISION 2. - CLERK[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Clerk of superior court generally, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-50 et seq. 

Sec. 1-3-71. - Fee system abolished. 
The present mode of compensating the clerk of the superior court of Lamar County is abolished and in lieu thereof an annual salary for such officer is prescribed as hereinafter provided. 
(Acts 1984, p. 3904, § 1) 
State Law reference— Minimum salary of clerk of superior court, O.C.G.A. § 15-6-88 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3-72. - Fees, etc., to property to county. 
After the effective date of this act, said officer [the clerk of the superior court] shall diligently and faithfully undertake to collect all fees, fines, forfeitures, commissions, costs, allowances, penalties, funds, moneys, and all other emoluments and perquisites formerly allowed as compensation for services in any capacity in his office and shall receive and hold the same in trust for said county as public moneys and shall pay the same into the county treasury on or before the fifteenth day of each month next following the month in which they were collected or received. At the time of each such monthly payment into the county treasury, said officer shall furnish the governing authority of the county a detailed, itemized statement, under oath, of such funds received during the preceding month by such officer and paid into the county treasury. The statement shall show the respective amounts of money collected and the source thereof. 
(Acts 1984, p. 3904, § 3) 
Sec. 1-3-73. - Personnel. 
The clerk [of the superior court] shall have the authority to appoint such deputies, clerks, assistants, and other personnel as he shall deem necessary to efficiently and effectively discharge the official duties of his office. The clerk shall, from time to time, recommend to the governing authority of said county the number of such personnel needed by his office, together with the suggested compensation to be paid each employee; however, it shall be within the sole discretion of the governing authority of Lamar County to fix the compensation to be received by each employee in said office. It shall be within the sole power and authority of the clerk to designate and name the person or persons who shall be employed as such deputies, clerks, assistants, or other employees, and to prescribe their duties and assignments and to remove or replace any of such employees at will and within his sole discretion. 
(Acts 1984, p. 3904, § 4) 
Sec. 1-3-74. - Expenses. 
The necessary operating expenses of the clerk's office, expressly including the compensation of all personnel and employees, shall be paid from any funds of the county available for such purpose. All supplies, materials, furnishings, furniture, utilities, and equipment and the repair, replacement, and maintenance thereof as may be reasonably required in discharging the official duties of said office shall be furnished by the county and shall be paid from any fund of the county available for such purpose. The determination of such requirements for said office shall be at the sole discretion of the governing authority of Lamar County. 
(Acts 1984, p. 3904, § 5) 
GEORGIA LAWS 
 This table is a chronological listing of local legislation. 

 
PART II - LAMAR COUNTY CODE 
Chapter 2-1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 2-1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances, resolutions and other enactments embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated, the Lamar County Code and may be so cited. 
Sec. 2-1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
The following definitions and rules of construction shall apply to all ordinances and resolutions of the board of commissioners unless the context requires otherwise: 
Generally. The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art, or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter, when they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade, or with reference to such subject matter. In all interpretations the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the board of commissioners, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil, and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(a), (b). 
Adequate. The word "adequate" means equal to what is required, suitable to the case or occasion, fully sufficient, proportionate, satisfactory. 
Aforesaid. The word "aforesaid" usually means next before, unless the context requires a different signification. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(4). 
All. The word "all" means every one, or the whole number of particulars. 
Also. The word "also" means "in like manner," "likewise," "in addition," "besides," "as well," "further," "too." 
As soon as possible. The term "as soon as possible" means within a reasonable time, having due regard to all the circumstances. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(5). 
At. The term "at" may mean "in," "near," "within," or "about." Its primary idea is nearness, and it is less definite than "in" or "on." 
Board of commissioners. The words "board of commissioners" shall mean the board of commissioners of Lamar County, Georgia. 
Code. The term "code" means the Lamar County Code as designated in section 2-1-1 above. 
Computation of time. When a number of days is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege, or the discharge of any duty, only the first or last day shall be counted; and if the last day shall fall on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge such duty. When the last day prescribed for such action shall fall on a public or legal holiday as set forth in state law, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following day to exercise such privilege or to discharge such duty; however, when said following day shall be a Saturday or Sunday, the party shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge such duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(3). 
County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean Lamar County, Georgia. 
Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the county to do some act or make certain inspections it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
Following. The word "following" usually means next after, unless the context requires a different signification. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(8). 
Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(4). 
Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons, or officers, may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(5). 
May. The word "may" is permissive. 
State Law reference— Definition of "may," O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(10). 
Month. The word "month" means a calendar month. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(11). 
Must. The word "must" is mandatory. 
Number. The singular and plural number shall include the other, unless expressly excluded. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(6). 
Oath. An "oath" includes an affirmation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(12). 
Or, and. "Or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the sense required it. 
Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
State Law reference— Definition of "person," O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(14). 
Preceding. The word "preceding" usually means next before, unless the context requires a different signification. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(15). 
Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(16). 
Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
Signature or subscription. A "signature" or "subscription" includes the mark of an illiterate or infirm person. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(19). 
State. The words "state" or "the state" shall mean the State of Georgia. 
Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the county. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
State Law reference— Tense of words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(7). 
Until a certain day. The term "until a certain day" includes all of such day. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(21). 
Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days. 
Whereas. The term "whereas" means "considering that." 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(22). 
Writing. The term "writing" includes printing and all numerals. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(23). 
Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(24). 
Sec. 2-1-3. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of legislation existing of the adoption date of this Code shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 2-1-4. - Matters not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any legislation promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the county, or any evidence of the county's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the county; 
(3)  Any right or franchise granted by the county to any person; 
(4)  Any legislation dedicating, naming, defining, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the county; 
(5)  Any appropriation or legislation authorizing appropriations or gifts; 
(6)  Any legislation providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; 
(7)  Any legislation establishing subdivision regulations or dedicating or accepting plat or subdivision in the county; 
(8)  Any zoning ordinance or resolution; 
(9)  Any legislation which is temporary, although general in nature; 
(10)  Any legislation which is special, although permanent in nature; 
(11)  Any legislation levying or otherwise relating to taxes; 
(12)  Any legislation establishing fees. 
Sec. 2-1-5. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any law in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 2-1-6. - Catchlines of sections. 
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 2-1-7. - Effective date of ordinances and resolutions. 
Ordinances and resolutions which do not provide for their taking effect at a different time, take effect immediately after their passage, or as otherwise provided by law. 
Sec. 2-1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances and resolutions. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not revive any ordinances or resolutions in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance or resolution repealed. 
Sec. 2-1-9. - Amendments; effect of new ordinances and resolutions; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances and resolutions passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances and resolutions, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances and resolutions as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances and resolutions until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted anew by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Lamar County Code, is hereby amended to read as follows:..." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Lamar County Code, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows:..." The new section may then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
Sec. 2-1-10. - Severability. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the board of commissioners without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
Sec. 2-1-11. - Violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in this Code the doing of an act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such provision shall be punished to the maximum extent allowed in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60. 
(b)  Each day any violation of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  In addition to the penalties provided in section or elsewhere in this Code, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance, and may be abated by the county as provided by law or ordinance. Each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
Cross reference— Magistrate court, § 1-3-26 et seq. 
Chapter 2-2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-2-1. - Legal opinions of county attorney. 
(a)  Legal opinions from the county attorney may be obtained: 
(1)  By the board of commissioners, or a member thereof, by request made at a meeting of the board of commissioners; 
(2)  By any county officer or employee, by filing a written request with the county administrator. The administrator shall forward the written request to the county attorney; 
(3)  By the Lamar County Sheriff, The Lamar County Tax Commissioner, The Lamar County Probate Judge, and the Lamar County Clerk of Superior Court, at any time in the performance of his/her duties he/she determines that a legal opinion is necessary. 
(b)  The county attorney is not obligated to render legal opinions except under the circumstances specified in subsection (a). 
(Res. of 6-5-50; Res. of 6-3-97) 
Sec. 2-2-2. - Records. 
The clerk of the board of commissioners is responsible for records management activities of the county. No record shall be destroyed except in accordance with approved retention schedules. 
(Res. of 10-4-83) 
State Law reference— Georgia Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-90 et seq.; records management programs for local governments, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-99. 
Sec. 2-2-3. - County car leaving county. 
No person shall take the county car out of the county for more than one (1) day without the approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Mo. of 11-16-84) 
Sec. 2-2-4. - Rental of county machinery to private persons. 
No person shall rent county machinery to private persons. 
(Mo. of 6-6-58) 
Sec. 2-2-5. - Courthouse office hours. 
The office hours of the courthouse shall be from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(Mo. of 6-22-84) 
State Law reference— Courthouse to remain open during normal working hours, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-12. 
Secs. 2-2-6—2-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Local acts relating to officers and employees, § 1-2-76 et seq.; courts, ch. 1-3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-2-26. - Commissioners' benefits eliminated. 
All county funded benefits for county commissioners shall be eliminated, effective January 5, 1999; this does not affect any current county commissioners' benefits being funded prior to January 5, 1999. 
(Res. of 1-5-99) 
Sec. 2-2-27. - Eligibility for benefits. 
All hired, elected and appointed employees shall work forty (40) hours to receive any employee benefits. 
(Mo. of 6-21-99) 
Sec. 2-2-28. - Self-insurance workers' compensation fund. 
Certain elected officials of Lamar County shall be covered under the Association of County Commissioners of Georgia Group Self-Insured Workers' Compensation Fund while performing their elected duties. The board of commissioners and the volunteer firemen shall be covered under the Worker's Compensation Laws of the State of Georgia. 
(Res. of 12-1-87; Res. of 2-21-00) 
State Law reference— Group self-insurance funds, O.C.G.A. § 34-9-150 et seq. 
Sec. 2-2-28.1. - Workmen's compensation salary. 
All employees paid by the hour shall receive the basic workmans' compensation salary and all salaried employees shall receive their regular weekly or monthly salary. 
(Res. of 9-5-89) 
Editor's note— A resolution adopted Sept. 5, 1989, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, its inclusion as § 2-2-28.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-2-29. - Social security. 
Social security coverage is extended to members of the sheriff's department. 
(Mo. of 1-6-76) 
State Law reference— Social security coverage for employees of local government, O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-2-30. - Retirement plan. 
The board of commissioners adopts a retirement program for its employees in accordance with the plan approved by the board of managers of the Association County Commissioners of Georgia. Plan participation shall be restricted to all persons who are current full-time county employees as of December 13, 1983, and who are not appointed to any position and/or office. No appointed part-time or hired part-time personnel shall be eligible for retirement benefits. 
(Res. of 12-13-83; Mo. of 9-7-93) 
Sec. 2-2-31. - Deferred compensation. 
The board of commissioners adopts the National Association of Counties Deferred Compensation Program and hereby establishes the Lamar County board of commissioners deferred compensation plan for the voluntary participation of all eligible county employees, elected officials and independent contractors. The county clerk is authorized to execute for the county individual participation agreements with each eligible employee requesting same. The county clerk shall act as the administrator of the plan and shall represent the county. He shall execute such agreements and contracts as are necessary to implement the program. Other than the incidental expenses of collecting and disbursing of the employees' deferrals and other minor administrative matters, there is to be no cost or contribution by the county to the program. 
(Res. of 4-5-83) 
Sec. 2-2-32. - Payment of license fees for truck drivers. 
The county will pay one-half (½) of the required license fee for the truck drivers in the road department. 
(Mo. of 1-3-84, § 3) 
Sec. 2-2-33. - Nepotism. 
(a)  Employment of relatives. There shall be nothing in these regulations to prohibit the employment of relatives by the county as long as neither of the related parties are employed in a supervisory role in which they might have either direct or indirect effect on the other party's progress, performance or welfare as a county employee. 
(b)  Supervision as it relates to nepotism. No individual shall be employed in a department or unit under the supervision of a relative who has or may have a direct effect on the individual's progress, performance or welfare. An employee may not be promoted into a position in which he would have supervisory responsibility over a relative, as defined by this policy, unless the relative can be transferred to another position to eliminate the necessity of the promoted employee supervising a relative. This policy will not affect present employees who are related where one (1) is presently in a supervisory position. 
(c)  Definition of "relatives." For purposes of this nepotism policy, relatives are defined as husband and wives, parents and children, brothers, sisters, father-in-law, mother-in-law, sister-in-law, brother-in-law, son-in-law, or daughter-in-law, guardian, grandparents, grandchildren, including the various combinations of half, step and adopted relationships that can be derived from those named. 
(Res. of 6-7-88, §§ A—C) 
Editor's note— A resolution adopted June 7, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ A—C as § 2-2-33 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-2-34. - Appointed or part-time personnel. 
No appointed or hired part-time personnel shall be eligible for group health insurance or retirement benefits. 
(Mo. of 3-19-91; Mo. of 9-7-93) 
Editor's note— A motion of March 9, 1991, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 2-2-34 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-2-35. - Pension plan for volunteer firemen. 
Effective January 1, 1996 with a limit of twenty (20) members per station and a probation period of thirty (30) days, there will be a pension for volunteer firemen funded by the county. 
(Mo. of 12-5-95) 
Sec. 2-2-36. - Employee benefit classifications for group health insurance. 
Three (3) employee benefit classifications are created and defined for eligibility for group health insurance to be paid by the employer. Such classifications are as follows: 
(1)  Class I. All hired employees working at least thirty (30) hours per week. 
(2)  Class II. All elected employees working at least seventeen and one-half (17.5) hours per week. 
(3)  Class III. All appointed employees working at least seventeen and one-half (17.5) hours per week. 
(Mo. of 9-7-93) 
Editor's note— A motion of Sept. 7, 1993, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as § 2-2-36 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-2-37. - Retiree recognition. 
All employees who retire with at least ten (10) years service shall receive a plaque and a retirement dinner from the county. 
(Mo. of 3-19-91) 
Secs. 2-2-38—2-2-50. - Reserved.

The Lamar County Board of Commissioners hereby adopts the Lamar County Personnel Policy, in the form attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference as Exhibit "A", and as amended from time to time, as the personnel policy for all employees of Lamar County.

DIVISION 4. - VEHICLE USE POLICY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— County car leaving county, § 2-2-3. 

Sec. 2-2-75.11. - Unauthorized use, misuse prohibited. 
Unauthorized use or misuse of county equipment and/or vehicles is strictly prohibited. 
(Mo. of 6-6-00, § A) 
Sec. 2-2-75.12. - "Take-home" restrictions. 
Vehicle(s) assigned to an individual may be taken to their residence and parked when needed in furtherance of county business and approved by the individual's department head or the county administrator provided the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The individual must reside inside or within five (5) driving miles of the boundaries of Lamar County; 
(2)  The individual must be able to provide off-street parking and adequate security that includes, as a minimum, the ability to easily observe the parked vehicle; 
(3)  The individual must submit a request for permission to take a vehicle home if he or she lives out of the county and can meet the above requirements; 
(4)  The individual's request must be submitted to the individual's department head and placed on file with the department and in the office of the board of commissioners; 
(5)  When the parking of departmental vehicles (either in county or out) doesn't meet the above standards, the vehicle will be parked at one (1) of the following locations: 
a.  At the office of each department; 
b.  At any Lamar County Emergency Services fire station. 
(Mo. of 6-6-00, § B) 
Sec. 2-2-75.13. - Authorized passengers. 
Members of the department shall not transport, or otherwise have, personnel in their vehicles who are not members of the department or employed by the county except: 
(1)  Person(s) under arrest; 
(2)  Person(s) who are the victims of a crime or traffic accident; 
(3)  Person(s) whose transportation is a matter of departmental concern; 
(4)  Certified Georgia law enforcement officers acting as observers and who have signed a waiver of liability and are approved by the sheriff; 
(5)  Those person(s) not otherwise qualified to ride but who are approved on a case-by-case basis by the department head; 
(6)  Person(s) listed in paragraphs (4) and (5) above shall prepare and submit a waiver of liability, in a format approved by the department head or the county administrator, prior to actually "riding" as a patrol observer; 
(7)  Members of the department will not carry persons as "patrol observers" until such time as a waiver is properly completed and placed on file. A new waiver must be completed and initialed by the department head for each individual rider and forwarded to the department for filing and to the office of the board of commissioners. 
(Mo. of 6-6-00, § C) 
Sec. 2-2-75.14. - Vehicle inspections. 
Departmental vehicles shall be inspected by the department head or his or her designee on a monthly basis. The department head or his or her designee shall conduct monthly inspections of any reserve vehicles. This inspection shall be for: 
(1)  Cleanliness; 
(2)  Overall mechanical condition and soundness; 
(3)  The presence and condition of required auxiliary equipment such as: 
a.  Emergency lights and siren; 
b.  Radio equipment; 
c.  Flashlight; 
d.  Cage; 
e.  Fire extinguisher; 
f.  First aid kit; 
g.  Blanket; and 
h.  Any other equipment deemed necessary by the department. 
(Mo. of 6-6-00, § D) 
Secs. 2-2-75.15—2-2-75.20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TRAVEL POLICY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Motion of 10-11-05 amended Div. 5, in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Div. 5, derived from Mo. of 1-27-04. 

Sec. 2-2-75.21. - Introduction. 
These travel and expense regulations are designed to assist Lamar County elected and appointed officials and employees (hereafter collectively called "employee(s)") who are required to travel away from their official headquarters in the course of performing their official duties, and aid the county in the payment of travel expenses. Each employee required to travel is entitled to reimbursement for reasonable, necessary and allowable expenses incurred. These regulations are intended to indicate what constitutes reasonable and necessary expenses and to provide uniformity among various departments of county government. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05) 
Sec. 2-2-75.22. - Statement of purpose. 
It is the county's purpose to allow travel arrangements on a limited basis provided (a) travel appropriations are available, (b) travel is duly authorized and (c) travel is within the scope of the employee's employment and the discharge of his/her official duties. Employees are expected to show good judgment and proper regard for economy in incurring travel expenses. Required records must be kept of expenditures at the time incurred, submitted on the appropriate expense report and completed in strict accordance with these regulations. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05) 
Sec. 2-2-75.23. - Approval of reimbursement claims. 
Reimbursement claims for subsistence (meals and lodging), transportation, and miscellaneous expenses are to be reported on a "travel expense statement" form provided by the county by date, location, and amount for each meal, lodging and other allowable expenses claimed (example attached). Reimbursement claims submitted by employees other than elected officials, the county administrator and appointed department heads shall be approved by the appropriate department head. All reimbursement claims submitted shall be approved by the county administrator and three (3) commissioners and/or the chairman prior to payment. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05) 
Sec. 2-2-75.24. - Meal allowance. 
Elected officials and employees will be reimbursed for the costs of meals (excluding alcohol) as follows: 
(1)  Overnight trip outside of Lamar County. Expenses for three (3) meals per day may be claimed in an amount not to exceed forty dollars ($40.00) per day, including tips and taxes, where their destination is outside of the jurisdictional limits of Lamar County and overnight travel is required. Receipts are required and shall be attached to the request for reimbursement. 
(2)  Single day trip outside of Lamar County. Expenses for three (3) meals per day may be claimed in an amount not to exceed twenty dollars ($20.00) per day, including tips and taxes, where their destination is outside of the jurisdictional limits of Lamar County and no overnight travel is required. Receipts are required and shall be attached to the request for reimbursement. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-12, § 1, adopted August 10, 2010, repealed the former § 2-2-75.24, and enacted a new § 2-2-75.24 as set out herein. The former § 2-2-75.24 pertained to subsistence and derived from Mo. of October 11, 2005. 
Sec. 2-2-75.25. - Lodging. 
Reimbursement may be made for actual lodging expenses based on reasonable rates. All lodging claims must be documented with receipts. Travelers should always endeavor to obtain suitable accommodations at the most economical rates available. It is expected that reservations will be made in advance whenever practical, that minimum rate accommodations available will be utilized, that "deluxe" hotels/motels will be avoided and that government rates will be obtained whenever possible. Reimbursement will be made for the actual amount of the bill. Other lodging rates are allowable when the employee is staying at a hotel officially associated with the conference or seminar that the individual is attending and government rates are not available. Exceptions may also be justified when the travel is of an emergency nature. Local government employee(s) should not be charged local hotel/motel excise tax on lodging while traveling on official government business inside the state. The form "Exemption of the Local Hotel/Motel Excise Tax" (see form attached to Mo. of 10-11-05) is to be completed and presented at the hotel registration desk when registering. Reimbursement for lodging shall be limited to the minimum number of nights required to conduct the assigned county business. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 2) 
Sec. 2-2-75.26. - Transportation. 
Departments should approve transportation cost based on the most economical mode, consistent with the purpose of the travel. 
(a)  Air, rail, bus, taxi and car rental. This service during out of town business will be reimbursed if such service is reasonable and necessary to the conduct on county business. All shall be at the most economical rate available and receipts are required for reimbursement of the transportation cost. 
(b)  Personal vehicles. 
1.  Reimbursement for transportation expenses incurred by the use of personally owned vehicles will be at the then-current mileage rate allowed by the Internal Revenue Service. The authorized mileage rate is intended to cover the normal expenses incurred in the operation of a personal vehicle. The initial point of departure shall be the individual's home or normal place of work, whichever is nearer the destination point or depending on which one of the places (home or work) the employee is initially leaving from. When possible, employees should attempt to travel together to the same destination in one (1) vehicle. 
2.  In addition, parking, shuttle, and toll expenses will be paid for official travel. A receipt shall be provided for reimbursement. 
3.  Employees sharing a ride with another person using either a personal or county vehicle will not claim reimbursement for the miles traveled. 
(c)  County vehicles. County vehicles may be provided for travel when authorized by the county department head and a vehicle is available for said purposes. 
In addition, parking, shuttle, and toll expenses will be reimbursed for official travel. A receipt shall be provided for reimbursement. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 3) 
Sec. 2-2-75.27. - Registration fees. 
Fees required for participation in workshops, seminars and conferences which an employee is directed or authorized to attend shall be paid by a county check in advance. However, if an employee is required to pay the registration fee, reimbursement will be made when supported by a paid receipt or copy of the check showing payment. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 4) 
Sec. 2-2-75.28. - Miscellaneous expenses. 
(a)  Business telephone/fax. Expenses [Reimbursement] for official telephone/fax expenses are [is] allowable. 
(b)  Personal telephone charges. Every official employee will be allowed a reasonable cost per day for personal long distance telephone calls while out of the county on official county business. 
(c)  Other charges. Claims for laundry, valet service, shoe shines, theatre, movies or videos, entertainment, excessive personal telephone calls, tobacco products, alcoholic beverages, etc. will not be reimbursed. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 5) 
Sec. 2-2-75.29. - Hospitality meals/other expenses. 
County employees and officials may be required to meet with persons of other organizations or other officials to exchange information to benefit Lamar County. When in the opinion of the county commissioners or the county administrator there is such a need, it shall be appropriate to pay for meals or other costs as deemed appropriate. A receipt is required and the purpose of the business topic/project must be documented on the expense report. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 6) 
Sec. 2-2-75.30. - County credit cards. 
The only charges authorized to county credit cards or hotel accounts are charges allowed under the county travel policy as follows: 
(a)  Lodging room rate; 
(b)  Parking; 
(c)  Telephone charges for business calls and reasonable cost for personal calls; 
(d)  Hospitality expenses as defined in section 2-2-75.29; 
(e)  Meal expenses as defined in section 2-2-75.24; 
(f)  Credit cards must be signed out before leaving for a trip and returned upon returning from the trip. The county credit card shall not be used for any purpose other than authorized under this policy. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 7) 
Sec. 2-2-75.31. - Extraordinary travel or cost. 
The county administrator, upon recommendation of the board of commissioners or the department head, may approve travel not covered by this policy. However, the terms must be determined before the travel occurs or before the cost is incurred. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 8) 
Sec. 2-2-75.32. - Procedure for authorization to travel. 
The employee must submit a request for travel to the county department head, which shall include sufficient justification to permit approval. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 9) 
Sec. 2-2-75.33. - Reimbursement procedures. 
A diligent effort should be made by department heads and persons responsible for approving claims for travel reimbursement to see that expense statements submitted are reasonable, accurate and cover only expenses actually incurred by an employee traveling in the interest of the county. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 10) 
Sec. 2-2-75.34. - Statement of propriety. 
Each county employee on travel status should consider seriously the wording of the statement to be signed in submitting a claim for reimbursement, which reads as follows: 
"I do solemnly swear, under penalty of a felony for false statements subject to punishment by not less than one year nor more than twenty years of penal servitude, that the above statements are true and I have incurred the described expenses including mileage in the discharge of my official duties for the County, or for other approved duties shown above. I further solemnly swear that I will not receive reimbursement from any other sources, public or private, for the above expenditures." See Section 16-10-20 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
(Mo. of 10-11-05, § 11) 
Secs. 2-2-75.35—2-2-75.39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - RETURN TO WORK PROGRAM 

Sec. 2-2-75.40. - Policy. 
It is the policy of Lamar County to provide and establish a return to work policy and procedure for employees with work-related injuries and illnesses who are unable temporarily and permanently, to return to their permanent job duties. 
Because Lamar County recognizes that their employees are a valued and limited resource, this program is designed to: 
•  Assist the medical recovery process by providing a focus and a goal for return of the injured employee. 
•  Benefit employees by allowing them to return to full wages as soon as possible. 
•  Benefit employer by reducing workers' compensation costs. 
(Mo. of 9-3-02) 
Sec. 2-2-75.41. - Process. 
The county will seek return to work opportunities through the use of transitional employment for all employees who are temporarily disabled due to on-the-job injury as quickly as medically possible. Transitional employment opportunities will be considered in all departments, not just the department in which the injured employee was working before the injury or illness occurred. 
Transitional employment assignments are intended to assist workers who are transitioning back to work after temporary disability that resulted from a work-related injury. All transitional employment duties must be productive. Duties must never be demeaning or appear worthless in any way. 
The county, through its reasonable accommodation program, will make efforts to retain employees who are permanently disabled. 
(Mo. of 9-3-02) 
Sec. 2-2-75.42. - Safety discount. 
In compliance with the Association [of] County Commissioners of Georgia-Group Self Insured Workers' Compensation Fund (ACCG-GSIWCG) safety discount program, the county agrees to adopt this return to work policy and attend at least one (1) training session on implementation of the return to work program in a calendar year. 
(Mo. of 9-3-02) 
ARTICLE III. - COUNTY CLERK/ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-2-76. - References in Code. 
In this Code any reference to the "county clerk" or to the "administrator" shall refer to the county clerk/administrator provided for in this article. 
Sec. 2-2-77. - Tenure. 
The administrator serves at the pleasure of the board of commissioners. 
(Mo. of 6-9-83; Mo. of 1-19-93) 
Sec. 2-2-78. - Desirable knowledge, skills and abilities. 
The following are desirable knowledge, skills, and abilities for the administrator: 
(1)  Extensive knowledge of county organization and functions, and relationships within the government and among other levels of government; 
(2)  Thorough knowledge of the basic principles of public administration with particular emphasis on personnel administration and budgeting; 
(3)  Thorough knowledge of research methods and techniques, and methods of report presentation; 
(4)  Considerable knowledge of the sources of grants and other financial resources, and the ability to prepare an acceptable grant applications; 
(5)  Thorough knowledge of modern office practices and methods; 
(6)  Ability to assemble, organize and present in written or oral form statistical, financial, or factual information derived from a variety of sources; 
(7)  Ability to express ideas clearly and concisely, both orally and in writing; 
(8)  Ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with other employees, county officials and the public. 
(Mo. of 6-9-83) 
Sec. 2-2-79. - Desirable training and experience. 
The following are desirable training and experience for the administrator: 
(1)  Graduation from an accredited college or university with courses in business administration, political science, or public administration; 
(2)  Considerable progressively responsible experience in a staff or administrative capacity in local government, preferably on the county level; or 
(3)  Any equivalent combination of training and experience. 
(Mo. of 6-9-83) 
Sec. 2-2-80. - Functions. 
(a)  The position of administrator involves the responsibility of county clerk. The clerk serves as executive secretary to the board of commissioners. 
(b)  The administrator is responsible for administering and coordinating the daily operations of all departments of the county, under the guidance and supervision of the board of commissioners. The position requires the employee to possess varied administrative skills, including personnel administration, budget preparation and analysis, data collection, records control and effective techniques of organizational management. Work assignments flow from directives issues by the board of commissioners as well as from requests for information and/or assistance from the citizenry. The administrator is expected to keep abreast of county problems and shall inform the board of commissioners of such problems and offer possible solutions for correcting or alleviating them. 
(c)  The administrator shall supervise the heads of each department function, as well as small clerical staff whose job is to assist the administrator in the performance of his duties. The performance of the administrator is evaluated primarily through the evaluation of the effectiveness of county operations and by reviewing required reports. 
(d)  The following are examples of duties of the administrator: 
(1)  Act as the chief administrative officer of the county, directly responsible to the board of county commissioners, insuring the proper administration of all affairs of the county. 
(2)  Receive requests and complaints from the public concerning administrative actions of the various departments, channel the requests to appropriate departments, follow up on the corrective actions, and see that replies to inquires are given. 
(3)  Serve as county personnel officer; analyze jobs to delineate position responsibilities for use in wage and salary adjustments, promotion, and evaluation of workflow; and study methods of improving work measurements or performance standards. 
(4)  Employ, train and discharge employees, supervise and coordinate activities and determine work procedures; assign duties to employees and examine work for accuracy and adherence to standards. 
(5)  Recommend to the board of commissioners the adoption of policies deemed necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the county, or the improvement of administrative services. 
(6)  Study management methods in order to improve workflow, simplify reporting procedures, or implement cost reductions; analyze unit operating practices, such as bookkeeping and record keeping systems, forms control, office layout, suggestion systems, personnel requirements, and performance standards, to create new systems or revise established procedures. 
(7)  Prepare reports including conclusions and recommendations for solution of administrative problems; upon direction of the board of commissioners and with general policy guidance, prepares directives to department heads. 
(8)  Coordinate collection and preparation of operating reports, such as time and attendance records, terminations, new hires, transfers, budget expenditures and statistical records of performance data. 
(9)  Prepare and submit to the board of commissioners an annual budget together with a complete report on the finances and activities of the county for the proceeding year, delineate and justifies requests for expenditures for new programs. In performing these duties, the clerk/administrator also shall serve as budget officer. 
(10)  Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies, and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget. 
(11)  Keep the board of commissioners informed of the financial condition and future needs of the county, and make such recommendations as deemed desirable. 
(12)  Prepare grant applications for any other applications necessary for the receipt of funds for county programs; work with federal, state and regional officials providing them with any information necessary to receive or continue receiving outside funds. 
(13)  Attend all meetings of the board of commissioners, unless otherwise excused therefrom, and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the board of commissioners. 
(14)  Perform related duties as required. 
(Mo. of 6-9-83; Mo. of 8-21-01) 
Sec. 2-2-81. - Clerk/administrator to inform board if motion will change Code. 
The clerk/administrator will inform the board if a motion will change the Code. 
(Mo. of 1-7-93) 
Secs. 2-2-82—2-2-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL AFFAIRS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Local acts relating to financial affairs, § 1-2-201 et seq.; licenses and taxation, ch. 2-12. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-2-101. - Investment of funds. 
Funds not needed for monthly bills and payroll shall be invested in certificates of deposit. The certificates shall be divided so that the dates of maturity are staggered. 
(Mo. of 1-3-84, § 2) 
Sec. 2-2-102. - Checks and warrants. 
Checks and warrants on the county will be issued and signed by the chairman and the county clerk/administrator. In the absence of the chairman, the vice-chairman and the clerk will sign them. In the absence of the clerk/administrator, the deputy clerk will sign. 
(Mo. of 1-3-84, § 1) 
Secs. 2-2-103—2-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING POLICY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note— Chapter 2-2, Art. IV, Div. 2, §§ 2-2-111—2-2-124 was deleted as being superseded by an ordinance of July 2, 1991, to read as herein set out at the discretion of the editor. Former Art. IV, Div. 2, pertained to the purchasing policy and derived from an ordinance of Jan. 20, 1984, §§ 1—14. 

Sec. 2-2-111. - Title. 
This division shall be known as the "Lamar County Purchasing Policy." 
(Ord. of 2-7-91, § 1) 
Sec. 2-2-112. - Purpose; adoption. 
(a)  Purpose. [The purpose of this purchasing policy is:] 
(1)  To insure the orderly, efficient, fair and economical purchase of equipment and supplies for county use; and 
(2)  To insure that purchases are made from local or state vendors wherever feasible. 
(b)  Adoption. The commissioners and department heads of Lamar County need specific and clear methods by which to handle both routine and emergency purchase, therefore, this purchasing policy is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. of 7-2-91, § 2) 
Sec. 2-2-113. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed: 
Governing authority, and/or board of commissioners shall mean the Lamar County Board of Commissioners. 
Purchasing agent shall mean the county clerk/administrator or a designee appointed to the position of purchasing agent by the clerk/administrator. 
Materials and supplies shall include such items as are normally used or consumed during the current year. 
Equipment shall include automotive equipment, machinery, construction contracts or other items of a permanent or semi-permanent nature. 
Emergency purchase shall mean a purchase for which a general appropriation in the budget has been made, and for which there is a compelling reason for immediate action for the protection and best interest for the county. 
Lamar County vendor shall include persons bidding or offering quotations for supplies, materials and/or equipment in his/her name or in the name of the firm or firms he/she represents, which person and/or firm(s) shall own real or personal property with taxes returnable to Lamar County. 
(1)  To be considered a "Lamar County vendor" the person or firm(s) must not be delinquent in payment of taxes due to Lamar County at the time of the bid. 
(2)  The burden of proof that a person or firm is a Lamar County vendor shall rest with the vendor. In the event of a disqualification by the purchasing agent of a Lamar County vendor, the vendor may appeal to the board of commissioners by a request properly placed on the board of commissioners' agenda. The board of commissioners shall render a decision on the matter which shall not be subject to further appeal. Any person or firm disqualified as a Lamar County vendor shall have the right to reapply to the purchasing agent to be considered a Lamar County vendor, but any appeal to the board of commissioners of a second or subsequent disqualification of the vendor by the purchasing agent cannot be made until at least ninety (90) days after the date of original disqualification. 
(Ord. of 7-2-91, § 4) 
Sec. 2-2-114. - Policies and procedures. 
(a)  Duties of a purchasing agent. 
(1)  The purchasing agent shall secure all materials, supplies and equipment of every kind and character required by the various departments of the county after first obtaining prices for the same. The purchasing agent shall inspect or delegate inspection of materials, supplies and equipment to see that they are what they are represented to be, and that the price and quality are the best that can be obtained in the local market or elsewhere. 
(2)  The purchasing agent must discharge his/her duties in such a manner as to assure fair competitive access to governmental business by responsible vendors, contractors, etc., and to foster public confidence in the integrity of Lamar County's procurement system. No gratuities, or favors of any nature shall be accepted by the purchasing agent, or any other employee, from vendors or potential vendors. 
(3)  The extent specified elsewhere herein, the purchasing agent is encouraged to favor Lamar County vendors over those outside of the county and Georgia vendors over those outside the state. 
(b)  Procurement policy. 
(1)  Materials, services and supplies shall be purchased only when monies for their cost have been appropriated and included in the annual budget of Lamar County. 
(2)  Materials, services and supplies shall be purchased only by the authority of the purchasing agent or the board of commissioners, following the procedures set forth in subsection (c) of this section. No officer or employee of the county shall purchase for or on behalf of the county any equipment, materials or supplies, or merchandise of any kind or character except through the purchasing agent; provided however, this section shall not apply in emergency purchases as specifically provided elsewhere herein. 
(3)  The purchasing agent shall have the authority to make purchases of materials and supplies or issue a purchase order for same without obtaining competitive bids where the purchase price does not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per unit. The purchasing agent shall, whenever feasible and economical, secure quotes from and make purchases from Lamar County vendors for the purchase of materials and supplies of this nature. 
(4)  Purchases of more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per unit but less than seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit may be made by the purchasing agent, after he/she or his/her designee has secured three (3) or more competitive bids or quotations, either verbal or written, for same. If less than three (3) vendors are available for such purchases, quotations must be secured from every available vendor prior to purchase. A purchase order for items in this category may be issued by the purchasing agent after consideration of price, service, durability, quality, delivery and any other information deemed pertinent to the public interest. The purchasing agent has the right to accept or reject any and all bids or quotations. 
(5)  The purchasing agent or his/her designee is authorized in his/her discretion to negotiate with and arrange for the purchase of items of more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per unit but less than seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit from a Lamar County vendor as opposed to a vendor outside Lamar County, when a quotation by the Lamar County vendor is not more than five (5) percent higher than a quotation given by a vendor outside of Lamar County. The purchasing agent or his/her designee is also authorized in his/her discretion to negotiate between Lamar County vendors whose quotations are within five (5) percent of each other and to choose between same and make such purchases in a manner that in the purchasing agent's discretion best meets the needs of Lamar County. 
(6)  The purchasing agent or his/her designee shall secure three (3) sealed bids for purchases of seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit or more. If less than three (3) vendors are available for such purchases, bids must be secured from every available vendor. 
(7)  Requests for sealed bids shall be clear and specific as to the items requested, including technical data, sketches, or blueprints if necessary and the particular brand or make of the supply, material or equipment, if appropriate. Requests for sealed bids shall state the date, time and location when bids will be opened. 
(8)  Sealed bids for purchases of seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit or more shall be opened by the purchasing agent or his/her designee at the location, date and time prescribed in the bid documentation. The bid opening is open to the public and vendors or their representatives are requested to be present. In order for their bids to be considered, Lamar County vendors or their representative must be present at the bid opening. 
(9)  The board of commissioners is authorized in its discretion to negotiate with and purchase items of more than seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit from a Lamar County vendor that has submitted a bid as opposed to a bidding vendor outside Lamar County, when a quotation by the Lamar County vendor is not more than five (5) percent higher than a quotation given by a vendor outside of Lamar County. The board of commissioners is also authorized in its discretion to negotiate between Lamar County vendors whose bids are within five (5) percent of each other and to choose between same and make such purchases in a manner that in the board of commissioners' discretion best meets the needs of Lamar County. 
(10)  Bids for items over seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit shall be awarded only after the board of commissioners has considered all relevant matters, including but not limited to price, service, durability, quality, delivery and any other information deemed pertinent to the public interest. Bid items must meet specifications set forth in the request to qualify. The board of commissioners has the right to accept or reject any and all bids. 
(11)  Requests for bids or quotations shall be made by the purchasing agent in such manner, in his/her discretion, as will enable free and open competition in the bidding. In the event calls for bids are advertised in a newspaper, such advertisement shall be run once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks, in the legal county paper before the bids are opened, unless otherwise provided by law. 
(12)  With regards to the purchase of items costing more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per unit but less than seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit, the purchasing agent must make a notation of all quotes or bids secured and keep a record of same. With regards to the purchase of items exceeding the cost of seventy-five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) per unit, all bids shall be kept on file by the purchasing agent. After an award has been or unenforceability shall, to the greatest extent allowed by law, not render invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable any of the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases of the ordinance and that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, all remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases of the ordinance shall remain valid, constitutional, enforceable, and of full force and effect. 
(13)  In the event a low bid for a specific purchase is not accepted, or in the event that no bid is accepted for a specific purchase, the purchasing agent shall make a note of the reasons for rejection of the low bid, or of all bids, and file same with the records involving the bids or quotations. If the purchase involved items costing more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) per unit, a copy of the portion of the minutes indicating the discussion and/or vote of the board of commissioners rejecting the bid or bids will suffice to meet this requirement of documentation. 
(c)  Purchasing procedures. 
(1)  No officer or employee of the county shall request any merchant, dealer or other vendor to deliver goods to the county except on a regular order from the purchasing agent, except in the case of emergency purchases as provided. 
(2)  Requests for the purchase of materials, supplies and equipment are to be originated in the requesting department and must be executed by the relevant department head. 
(3)  Requests are to be made on purchase requisition forms prepared in duplicate. The original is to be submitted to the purchasing agent, and the duplicate retained by the issuing department. 
a.  Requested items are to be clearly and completely described including technical data, sketches, blueprints, etc. when needed. 
b.  Preferred vendors and specifications may be suggested by the department head, but are not binding on the purchasing agent or the board of commissioners. 
c.  If the submitting department prefers a particular brand or make of an article, a valid reason for such preference must be noted on the requisition form. 
(4)  All requisition requests must be filled out with the proper budget code, and must be signed by the department head before being tendered to the purchasing agent. 
(5)  All properly signed requisitions will be compared to the budget by the purchasing agent. If rejected due to budget constraints or for any other reason, the purchasing agent will promptly inform the department head of the rejection and reasons therefore, and place the matter on the agenda for consideration at the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners. 
(6)  If approved, and under one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per unit, a purchase order will be issued and tendered to the department head or directly to the vendor, as the purchasing agent deems appropriate. 
(7)  Purchases of more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per unit but less than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) per unit may be made by a purchase order issued to the department head or directly to the vendor only after the purchasing agent or his/her designee has secured and compared quotations and otherwise followed the procedures set forth in subsections (b)(4) and (b)(5) above. 
(8)  In all cases where patented items are requisitioned by any department, the purchasing agent has authority to decide whether similar products of equal quality and at a lower price shall be ordered in lieu of such patented items. 
(9)  When supplies, materials and/or equipment arrives, all department heads will forward to the purchasing agent all receiving records (packing slips, labels, etc.) to verify receipt of the shipment. All receiving records must be dated and signed. If the shipment was not complete, the department head must indicate the omissions. (No partial payment will be made unless so specified before ordering). 
(10)  Any purchase made outside the procedures outlined above unless for a bona fide emergency will not be paid for with county funds but will be considered the obligation of the individual responsible for the purchase. 
(11)  Except in emergency situations, the purchasing agent, after a requisition for purchase has been made, shall make such purchase within ten (10) business days. 
(12)  The purchasing agent shall tender a copy of the Lamar County Purchasing Policy to each department head upon enactment. 
(13)  Each department head is charged with the ultimate responsibility to monitor and control his or her own budget. With this in mind, each department head should review and be aware of his/her department's current fiscal status as reflected in the monthly financial statement. 
(d)  Stock room purchases. 
(1)  Purchases of office supplies such as pencils, ribbons, paper, etc. will normally be handled by the purchasing agent or his/her designee. 
(2)  Due to limited space in the stockroom, some items will not be kept stocked. For such items, department heads should expect a delay of five (5) to ten (10) working days for delivery. 
(3)  A completed and properly-executed requisition form must be used for supplies obtained from the stock room. The requisition form must be given to the purchasing agent or his/her designee before any supplies are obtained. 
(4)  The purchasing agent will post charges for stockroom supplies to the appropriate department's account by the last day of each month. 
(e)  Emergency purchases. 
(1)  In all cases where there is an immediate need for any material, supplies, or equipment by any department, the department head shall write on the requisition form the words, "for emergency purposes" and a brief statement of the reason the department head considers the situation an emergency. 
(2)  When a requisition form marked for emergency purchases is received by the purchasing agent, it shall be his/her duty to give the same immediate attention. 
(3)  In the event an emergency should arise after office hours or on Sunday or a holiday, which emergency requires immediate action on the part of the department involved for the protection and best interest of the county, the purchase shall be made by the department head or the highest ranking department employee available, who shall then comply with the procedure set forth below in subsection (4). 
(4)  All emergency purchases made without a prior purchasing order shall be documented by an after-the-fact requisition form, stating that the purchase was made on an emergency basis and the reason for the emergency. The form shall be completed by the department head, or, if the department head is unavailable, by the employee who made the purchase, and tendered to the purchasing agent no later than 10:00 a.m. on the next business day following the emergency purchase. The form must include the name, address and telephone number of the vendor from whom the purchase was made. 
(5)  Upon receipt of an after-the-fact requisition form, the purchasing agent must determine whether or not an emergency truly existed and document the availability of funds from the budget for said purchase. 
(6)  If an emergency purchase exceeded fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) per unit, the purchasing agent must bring it to the attention of the chairman of the board of commissioners immediately, and the chairman shall indicate his/her approval of same by signing the after-the-fact requisition form. In any event, all emergency purchases exceeding twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) per unit must be brought to the attention of the entire board of commissioners no later than the next regular meeting following such purchase. 
(7)  If the purchasing agent (or the chairman of the board of commissioners, in the case of items exceeding fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) per unit) determines that the purchase was not an emergency, he/she must report same in writing to the board of commissioners, attaching to his/her report the after-the-fact purchase requisition, the invoice and all other relevant documentation. 
(8)  Any emergency purchase made outside the procedures outlined above and any emergency purchase not approved by either the purchasing agent or the board of commissioners will not be paid for with county funds but will be considered the obligation of the individual responsible for the purchase. 
(f)  Inspection and testing . The purchasing agent shall inspect or supervise the inspection of all supplies, materials and equipment on delivery to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the purchase order. The purchasing agent may, in his/her discretion, require chemical and physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries which are necessary to determine their quality and conformance with specifications. 
(g)  Repairs of equipment. 
(1)  It is recognized that repair and maintenance of equipment cannot be subjected to the same rules as purchase of equipment; however, it shall be the duty of the purchasing agent to exercise discretion in ordering repairs for any county-owned or leased equipment. 
(2)  Where, in the judgment of the purchasing agent, it is not feasible to secure competitive bids for repairs, every effort will be made to secure the lowest possible price for the repair, taking into consideration such factors as whether or not the person or firm offering the service is a Lamar County vendor, whether the service is warranted and for how long, prior experience of the county with the supplier and other factors deemed by the purchasing agent to be of importance. 
(3)  Any repair order which might reasonably be expected to exceed fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) shall receive prior approval of the board of commissioners before issuance of a purchasing order. 
(h)  Professional services. It is recognized that professional services, including but not limited to those of attorneys, physicians, accountants and architects, are not amenable to the bidding process and quality control governing the purchase of supplies, materials and equipment. Therefore, the acquisition of professional services for the county is left to the sound discretion of the board of commissioners. Whenever feasible, professionals residing or working in Lamar County shall be given preference over professionals without connection to Lamar County. 
(i)  Disposal of unserviceable materials, supplies and/or equipment. 
(1)  Subject to the provisions of relevant Georgia law, including O.C.G.A. § 50-16-144, and subject in to the approval of the board of commissioners, the purchasing agent shall be responsible for disposing of unserviceable county materials, supplies and equipment. 
(2)  If materials, suppliers or equipment becomes unserviceable, either by becoming obsolete, being replaced, or becoming dysfunctional to the point where it is unfeasible to use such property, or for other reasons, the department head responsible for the property shall bring its unserviceability to the attention of the purchasing agent, who shall bring the matter to the attention of the board of commissioners at its next regular meeting. 
(3)  If the fair market value of the unserviceable property is less than twenty-five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) per unit at the time of disposal, the purchasing agent shall sell or dispose of same in the way most beneficial to the county. Disposal may be by donation, by sale pursuant to bid, by auction, by trade-in, or in any other legal manner deemed feasible by the purchasing agent, but in every such event, the method of disposal is subject to the prior approval of the board of commissioners. 
(4)  If the board of commissioners deems fit, invitations to potential purchasers for sealed bids shall be made by the purchasing agent in such manner, in his/her discretion, as will enable free and open competition in the bidding. In the event calls for bids are advertised in a newspaper, such advertisement shall be run once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks, in the legal county paper before the bids are opened; unless the otherwise provided by law. 
(5)  In the disposal, donation or sale of unserviceable property, Lamar County persons or firms shall be given preference by the purchasing agent in generally the same fashion Lamar County vendors are favored in the purchase of materials, supplies and equipment. 
(6)  All funds from any sale of unserviceable property shall be documented in the purchasing agent's records and turned over to the county treasury upon receipt. A record of the disposal, donation, auction or sale of items of unserviceable property shall be kept in accordance with Georgia law. 
(j)  Information vendors; bidding list. 
(1)  Persons or firms who wish to be on the Lamar County vendors mailing list shall file a properly completed bidder's mailing list application, together with such other lists as may be attached to the application form. It is the purchasing agent's responsibility to provide such applications to interested persons and/or firms and to compile and periodically update a list of Lamar County vendors. 
(2)  When bids for materials, supplies or equipment are sought, the purchasing agent or his/her designee shall contact those persons or firms on the bidders mailing list who provide such materials, supplies or equipment, along with other potential vendors. 
(3)  It is not necessary to be on the bidders mailing list to be considered a Lamar County vendor entitled to such preferential treatment as is contained elsewhere in this ordinance. However, before any purchase is made from a Lamar County vendor on the basis of the preferential treatment specified elsewhere herein, the vendor must complete a bidders mailing list form and supply other pertinent information to the purchasing agent if requested. 
(4)  The purchasing agent, to the extent feasible, shall inform local and other vendors of Lamar County's purchasing policy and seek assistance from them in not accepting any requests for materials, supplies or equipment from any county employee without first having secured a properly authorized purchase order. The purchasing agent shall advise vendors to forward invoices to the board of commissioners and not to the department office. 
(5)  The purchasing agent shall tender copies of the Lamar County Purchasing Policy to all vendors on the bidders mailing list and to other vendors at the request. 
(Ord. of 7-2-91, § 5; Ord. No. 2009-02, § 1, 5-12-09; Ord. No. 2010-11, 8-10-10) 
Sec. 2-2-115. - Disbursement. 
The following procedures will be followed in making disbursements: 
(1)  The county clerk's signature and the signatures of at least three (3) county commissioners will be required; 
(2)  Disbursements will be made twice a month, on the tenth and twenty-fifth, or the first business day after said dates if those dates fall on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. 
(Res. of 3-17-92) 
Secs. 2-2-116—2-2-125. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-2-126. - Term limits for boards and commissions. 
The board of commissioners shall have an established term limit for each appointment made to a board or commission that shall be set for no more than four (4) years. 
(Res. of 6-22-04)

DIVISION 2. - BARNESVILLE-LAMAR COUNTY INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— City of Barnesville and County of Lamar development authority, § 1-2-251. 
State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-2-136. - Need found. 
There is determined and declared a pressing, existing and future need for a development authority to function in the county for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry, and employment opportunities in the county thereby promoting the general welfare of its citizenry. 
(Res. of 3-4-80) 
State Law reference— Statement of need required, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-4. 
Sec. 2-2-137. - Activated; renamed. 
The public body corporate and politic known as the "Development Authority" which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Development Authorities Law is activated. The same is renamed the Barnesville-Lamar County Industrial Development Authority. 
(Res. of 3-4-80) 
Sec. 2-2-138. - Municipal authorities not prohibited. 
This division does not affect the right of any municipal corporation in the county to create a development authority. 
(Res. of 3-4-80; Mo. of 6-5-84) 
Sec. 2-2-139. - Membership. 
The membership of the industrial development authority shall be eight (8): Four (4) county and four (4) city. 
(Res. of 2-20-96)
