All such persons sentenced under this section shall be required to correct or remedy such violations within the time as prescribed by the court, and in the absence of any such completion time being fixed by the court, within a reasonable time after such violation occurs. 
(Ord. of 7-8-03) 
Secs. 2-13-51—2-13-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUISANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, adopted June 22, 2004, amended art. III and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former art. III derived from Ord. of 7-08-03, § 1. 

Sec. 2-13-60. - Acts constituting nuisances designated. 
(a)  A "nuisance" is anything that works hurt, inconvenience or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinarily reasonable person. 
(b)  The following conditions, among others, may be declared to be nuisances: 
(1)  Stagnant water on premises; 
(2)  Any dead or decaying matter, weeds, vegetation or any fruit, vegetable, animal or rodent, upon premises which is odorous or capable of causing disease or annoyance to the inhabitants of the county; 
(3)  The pollution of public water or the injection of matter into the sewage system which would be damaging thereto; 
(4)  Maintaining a dangerous or diseased animal or fowl; 
(5)  Obstruction of a public street, highway or sidewalk without a permit; 
(6)  Loud or unusual noises which are detrimental or annoying to the public, including, without limitation, unusual loud disturbances in or around churches or multiple-family complexes such as loud music and other activities in swimming pool and clubhouse areas; 
(7)  In residential zoned districts (AR, ER, R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, P-M, P-R and O-1) with outdoor activities, electronically amplified sound or music from any source shall not be so loud to be determined a public nuisance. The following times and distances provide guidance for the determination of a noise nuisance: 
a.  Any plainly audible sound at one hundred (100) feet from the property line of the noise emanating site between the hours of 8:00 a.m. through 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 8:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
b.  Any plainly audible sound at fifty (50) feet from the property line of the noise emanating site between the hours of 10:00 p.m. through 8:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and 12:00 midnight through 8:00 a.m. on Friday and Saturday. 
(8)  All walls, trees and buildings that may endanger persons or property; 
(9)  Any business or building where illegal activities are habitually and commonly conducted in such a manner as to reasonably suggest that the owner or operator of the business or building was aware of the illegal activities and failed to reasonably attempt to prevent those activities; 
(10)  Unused or inoperable appliances, either gas or electric, of any size or type, including, but not limited to, iceboxes, refrigerators, washers, dryers, water heaters, televisions, stereos, or any parts thereof; 
(11)  Any trees, shrubbery or other plants or parts thereof, which obstruct clear, safe vision on roadways and intersections of the county; 
(12)  Junked or abandoned motor vehicles as defined in Code § 2-13-41; and 
(13)  Any other condition constituting a nuisance under state law. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 6-22-04; Ord. No. 2013-02, § 1, 8-20-13) 
Sec. 2-13-61. - Abatement of nuisances—Magistrate court authority. 
The magistrate court shall have full jurisdiction to try and dispose of all questions of nuisance affecting the public health or welfare. Any person who pleads guilty, nolo contendere or is convicted of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 2-1-11 or such other general law as may be enacted in the future to provide for punishment and penalties that may be imposed by the magistrate courts of the state. In addition to the fine and/or jail sentence, the judge may impose community service and require that the defendant abate or cure the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 6-22-04) 
Sec. 2-13-62. - Complaints of nuisance—Investigation and abatement order. 
(a)  Any official or inhabitant of the county may direct a complaint of nuisance to the code enforcement officer who shall investigate and may place the complaint on the magistrate court docket for a hearing upon the basis of the investigation. The magistrate court, after a ten-day notice to the party involved, shall hold a hearing thereon and upon finding that a nuisance does exist shall issue an order to the owner, agent in control of or tenant in possession, stating that a nuisance has been found to exist and that the nuisance must be abated within so many hours or days as the court shall deem reasonable, having consideration for the nature of the nuisance and its effect on the public. 
(b)  Animal control officers, license and building inspectors, and the sheriff's office shall and may also receive complaints, investigate the same and place on the court docket such complaints in the same manner as the code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 6-22-04) 
Sec. 2-13-63. - Abatement by county—Billing for costs. 
(a)  In any case where the owner, agent or tenant fails to abate the nuisance in the time specified, or where the owner, agent or tenant cannot be served with notice, or where the nature of the nuisance is such, in the opinion of the court that it must be immediately abated, the judge may issue an order to the sheriff directing the nuisance to be abated. The sheriff in such case shall keep record of the expenses and cost of abating same, and the costs shall be billed against the owner, agent or tenant for collection as for county revenues, and these shall become a lien against the property and the same shall be filed of record with the office of the clerk of superior court. 
(b)  Other county departments shall assist the sheriff as is necessary in abating nuisances hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 6-22-04) 
Sec. 2-13-64. - Summary abatement authorized when. 
Nothing contained in this chapter [article] shall prevent the board of commissioners from summarily and without notice ordering the abatement of or abating any nuisance that is a nuisance per se in the law or where the case is an urgent one and the health and safety of the public or a portion thereof is in imminent danger. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 6-22-04) 
Secs. 2-13-65—2-13-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-05, § 1, adopted October 18, 2011, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 2-13-60—2-13-62. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as §§ 2-13-80—2-13-82. 

Sec. 2-13-80. - Code enforcement officer created. 
There is created the position of Lamar County Code Enforcement Officer. The Code Enforcement Officer shall have only the authority and those duties granted to him by the Lamar County Board of Commissioners. The code enforcement officer shall report to the county administrator or, in his or her absence, the board of commissioners. The code enforcement officer shall have and enjoy any and all immunities as are now and hereafter granted to it or authorized by the Lamar County Code, the constitution and laws of this state. 
(Ord. No. 2011-05, § 1, 10-18-11) 
Sec. 2-13-81. - Code enforcement officer's authority. 
(a)  The code enforcement officer shall have the authority to enforce all provisions of the Lamar County Code of Ordinances and all applicable state codes, rules and regulations incorporated therein (hereinafter the "Code"). The code enforcement officer shall also have the authority to conduct such investigations as may be reasonably necessary to assure or compel compliance with the provisions of the Code, including accessing property and premises at reasonable times for the purpose of conducting investigations concerning matters regulated by the Code. 
(b)  No person shall obstruct, hamper or interfere with the code enforcement officer while in the process of executing his official duties. 
(Ord. No. 2011-05, § 1, 10-18-11) 
Sec. 2-13-82. - Code enforcement officer's duties. 
(a)  Duties. The duties of the code enforcement [officer] shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Enforcing the county's codes and ordinances by responding to complaints issued. 
(2)  Interpreting codes and ordinances for citizens. 
(3)  Issuing and serving warnings, notices, and citations for violations of county codes and ordinances. 
(4)  Conducting investigations of violations, which includes gathering evidence, interviewing witnesses, and preparing final case documentation for presentation in court. 
(5)  Testifying in court as an expert witness. 
(6)  Collecting on returned checks written to any department within Lamar County. 
(7)  Escorting houses that are transported through Lamar County to ensure that proper safety requirements are met. 
(8)  Performing related work as required. 
(9)  Discharging such other duties as may be required of him/her by the county administrator, chairman, and the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Investigations. The code enforcement officer shall promptly investigate complaints of violations of the Code and report his findings and actions to the county administrator and the board of commissioners. Wherever possible, the code enforcement officer shall use his best efforts to prevent violations or to detect and secure the correction of violations of the Code prior to taking legal action. 
(c)  Notice and citation. Upon his own investigation, being advised by another county department or by a citizen, or believing that a violation of any section of the Code exists, the code enforcement officer shall cause a written notice to be directed to the person or persons responsible for such violation and the owner of the property (if different), unless, in the discretion of the code enforcement officer, an emergency is deemed to exist. The notice should include the following: 
(1)  The person or persons responsible for the violation; 
(2)  The owner or occupant of the property; 
(3)  The address or location of the property; 
(4)  The nature of the violation, including the Code section(s) being violated, and applicable penalties; 
(5)  A course of action for curing the violation; 
(6)  A time frame for compliance; and 
(7)  A date for re-inspection for compliance. 
Following the expiration of the time set forth in the notice, the code enforcement officer shall cause a re-inspection to be performed. If the violation has not been remedied, the code enforcement officer shall issue a citation to the owner of the property and/or the responsible party for prosecution in accordance with the provisions for enforcement under the applicable Code section. 
(d)  Stop work orders. The code enforcement officer shall order discontinuance of any unlawful use of land, buildings or structures; removal of unlawful buildings or structures, including unlawful additions, alterations, or structural modifications; discontinuance of any unlawful work being performed; and shall pursue any other action authorized by the Code or the laws of the county or state to ensure compliance with, and prevent violations of, the provisions of the Code. 
(e)  Should a violation of the Code exist or be discovered, the code enforcement officer may confer with the county attorney who may then, in addition to other remedies provided by law, recommend that the county institute injunction, mandamus or any appropriate action or proceeding to prevent, enjoin, abate or remove such violation. The county attorney may also assist the code enforcement officer, upon request, to ascertain the owner of property under investigation. 
(f)  Emergencies. If the code enforcement officer believes that an emergency exists such that imminent harm or peril to life, health, or property is likely or is authorized by the Code, the code enforcement officer shall be authorized immediately to refer these matters, without notice to the owner, to the county attorney's office for immediate action as set forth under the applicable Code section or state law. 
(Ord. No. 2011-05, § 1, 10-18-11) 
Chapter 2-14 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Recreation advisory council or council means the Lamar County Recreation Advisory Council. 
Commission means the Lamar County Board of Commissioners. 
Commissioner means a member of the Lamar County Board of Commissioners, including the chairman. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Sec. 2-14-2. - Department established. 
There is hereby established a Lamar County Recreation Department, with the purpose of establishing, maintaining and managing sports and recreational programs, events and facilities for the use of all citizens of Lamar County. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Sec. 2-14-3. - Same—Funding; employees. 
The recreation department shall be funded and operated by the Board of Commissioners of Lamar County, and its employees and supervisors shall serve at the will of the commission. Funding for the employees, activities, and facilities shall be as approved by the commissioners pursuant to the county budget. The commission shall be vested with the powers, duties and obligations, necessary for the establishment, maintenance and conduct of a recreation system for all citizens of Lamar County in accordance with the laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Sec. 2-14-4. - City-owned recreation center. 
The recreation department is responsible for the care, maintenance, operation and supervision of the recreation center, pursuant to the lease between the commission and the City of Barnesville for same. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Sec. 2-14-5. - Budget; other funding. 
Annually, the director of the recreation department shall submit a proposed budget to the commission. In addition to the funds appropriated by the commission, it may accept any grant, device of real estate, or any gift or bequest of money or other personal property or any donation for use of recreation system. If, however, the acceptance thereof for such purposes will subject the commission to additional expense for improvements, maintenance or renewal, the acceptance of any grant or device of real estate shall be subject to the approval of the commission. Money received for such purposes, unless otherwise provided by the terms of the gift or bequest, shall be deposited in the funds of the commission. The commission may also charge nominal fees for various activities which may not be included in the original budget request. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Secs. 2-14-6—2-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION DEPARTMENT ADVISORY COUNCIL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 5-2-00 amended Art. II, §§ 2-14-26—2-14-35, in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to the recreation commission and derived from Ord. of 3-2-71, §§ 1—5, 7, 8 and 10; Res. of 12-29-88, §§ 1—3; and Ord. of 4-12-94. 

Sec. 2-14-26. - Establishment; purpose. 
An advisory body of five (5) members to be known as the Lamar County Recreation Advisory Council, is established for the purpose of providing input, recommendations and reports to the commission with regards to the recreation programs, systems, and facilities. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A; Mo. of 4-17-01) 
Sec. 2-14-27. - Composition. 
The members of the council shall be appointed by the commission, with each commissioner (including the chairman of the board of commissioners) responsible for appointing one (1) member. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A; Mo. of 4-17-01) 
Sec. 2-14-28. - Appointment, compensation of members. 
The first appointments to the council shall be made as soon as practicable upon the adoption of this article; and subsequent appointments shall be made at the first commission meeting of each year following a year in which any commissioner was elected. Members shall serve without pay. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Sec. 2-14-29. - Terms of members. 
The term of each member shall be contemporaneous to that of the term of the commissioner who appointed such member. At the first meeting of the year in which a new or re-elected commissioner takes office, that commissioner shall appoint his or her designee to the council. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A; Mo. of 4-17-01) 
Sec. 2-14-29.1. - Right of the chairman or member of county board of commissioners to attend meetings. 
The five (5) members of the council shall constitute the advisory council; however, the chairman of the county board of commissioners or a commission member designated by the board shall be notified of, and have the right to attend meetings. No voting rights shall be extended to the chairman or designated member of the board of commissioners, but he or she shall be heard on any issues or questions that come before the council. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A; Mo. of 4-17-01) 
Sec. 2-14-30. - Organization; adoption of bylaws and regulations. 
Immediately after appointment of the first members, the council shall meet and organize by electing one (1) of its members as chairperson and provide for such other officers as may be necessary. The council shall have the power to adopt bylaws and rules for its conduct. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A) 
Sec. 2-14-31. - Duty to provide input and recommendations. 
The advisory council shall provide input, reports and recommendations to the board of commissioners at such times as either the council or the commission deems appropriate, on such subjects as the council and the commission deem appropriate, with the purpose of offering constructive advice and counsel with regards to the conduct and supervision of public playgrounds, playfields, indoor recreation centers, and other recreation facilities owned or controlled by the county and on private properties with consent of the owners. A report including general recommendations shall be offered by the advisory council to the commission at least annually. 
(Ord. of 5-2-00, Exh. A)

ARTICLE III. - BUTTS-HENRY-LAMAR-SPALDING COUNTY JOINT DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-15-41. - Inclusion of Lamar County. 
It is resolved by the board of commissioners of Butts County, Georgia, the board of commissioners of Henry County, Georgia, the board of commissioners of Lamar County, Georgia, and the board of commissioners of Spalding County, Georgia, that The Butts-Henry-Spalding County Joint Development Authority be amended to include Lamar County, Georgia, and by this amended and restated Concurrent Resolution, there is hereby continued in effect a body corporate and politic now to be known as The Butts-Henry-Lamar-Spalding County Joint Development Authority (the "Authority"). 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-42. - Purpose. 
Each of the boards of commissioners severally finds and declares that there is a need for a joint development authority to function in Butts, Henry, Lamar, and Spalding Counties in order to promote trade, commerce, industry, and employment opportunities; for the public good and the general welfare; and to promote the general welfare of the state and to reduce unemployment to the greatest extent possible within Butts, Henry, Lamar, and Spalding Counties. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-43. - Authority. 
This article is adopted pursuant to the Development Authorities Law (Chapter 62 of Title 63 of the Official Code of Georgia) as the same was amended by The General Assembly of Georgia at the 1995 Session thereof and is intended to comply therewith and shall be governed thereby for the purpose of permitting business enterprises in the four (4) counties to qualify for the tax credits given for each new full-time job created and for all other purposes permitted by said Act. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-44. - Membership; terms. 
(a)  The authority shall be governed by a board of directors consisting of three (3) tax paying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Butts County, Georgia, from the members of the Butts County Industrial Development Authority, three (3) tax paying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Henry County, Georgia, from the members of the Henry County Development Authority, three (3) tax paying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Lamar County, Georgia, from the members of the Lamar County Development Authority, and three (3) tax paying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Spalding County, Georgia, from the members of the Griffin Spalding County Development Authority. 
(b)  The board of commissioners of Lamar County shall initially appoint one member for the remainder of a one-year term expiring on December 31, 1996, one (1) member for the remainder of a two-year term expiring on December 31, 1997, and one (1) member for the remainder of three-year term expiring on December 31, 1998. As each of the terms expire the successor appointee shall be appointed for a three year term. The members heretofore appointed by Butts County, Henry County and Spalding County shall continue to serve for the terms already appointed with their successors to be appointed for three-year terms each as present terms expire on December 31 of each year. The appointees by each county must be residents of such county, and if a director ceases to be a resident of the county from which appointed, such director shall cease to be eligible for membership and shall be replaced. In addition to the appointed members, the executive director of each of the four (4) development authorities shall serve as a nonvoting ex officio member. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-45. - Compensation. 
The directors shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be reimbursed for their actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-46. - Appointment of chair and committees. 
The board of directors shall elect a chair, a vice-chair, a secretary-treasurer, and such other officers, and the chair shall appoint such committees, as shall be necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of and to conduct the affairs of the authority. A majority of the directors shall constitute a quorum, but no action may be taken by the board without the affirmative vote of a majority of the full membership of the board. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-47. - Meetings. 
The board of directors shall meet quarterly on the second Wednesday of January, March, June, and September of each year. The meeting place shall rotate among Butts, Henry, Lamar, and Spalding Counties, pursuant to written notice to be sent by the secretary at least seven (7) days before each meeting. Special meetings may be held at the call of the chair or any three (3) directors upon such reasonable notice as the exigencies of the situation permit. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-48. - Bylaws and regulations. 
(a)  The authority may make bylaws and regulations for its governance and may delegate to one (1) or more of its officers, agents and employees such powers and duties as may be deemed necessary and proper the authority shall have perpetual existence. 
(b)  The bylaws and the operational business plan of the authority shall be amended to comprehend the entry of Lamar County into this authority. The bylaws and operational business plan may be amended at any regular or called meeting of the authority by a majority of all the directors, provided, that written notice of the proposed amendment shall have been furnished to each director at least two (2) weeks in advance of the meeting where the change is to be considered. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Sec. 2-15-49. - Amendments. 
This resolution may be amended at any time by concurrent resolution of the boards of commissioners of Butts, Henry, Lamar and Spalding Counties, Georgia. 
(Res. of 10-3-95) 
Chapter 2-16 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic, ch. 2-17; streets in subdivisions, App. B, §§ XI, XII. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-16-1. - Specifications for roads county will accept. 
(a)  The county will not accept deeds to roads unless they comply with this section. 
(b)  The right-of-way shall be at least eighty (80) feet wide. The finished road shall be at least twenty-eight (28) feet wide. The paving shall be at least twenty-four (24) feet wide. There shall be shoulders on each side of the road. Each shoulder shall be at least five (5) feet wide. The completed base shall be at least six (6) inches. 
(c)  Cut sections shall have a front slope of three (3) to one (1), a back slope of a minimum of one (1) to one (1). The ditch shall be at least two (2) feet deep. 
(d)  Fill sections shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Sections of one (1) foot to five (5) feet require a three (3) to one (1) slope; 
(2)  Sections of five (5) feet or more require a two (2) to one (1) slope. 
(e)  The pipe cover (c.d.) shall be at least one (1) foot. All pipe shall be staked to meet slopes both in full and cut sections according to department of transportation standards. 
(f)  The pipe cover (s.d.) shall be at least six (6) inches before placing the base. 
(g)  All cross drains shall have tail ditches if required. When grading from a cut section to a fill section the water is to be diverted from the fill section. Cross drains shall have a channel excavation if required. All pipe shall have a fall. 
(h)  Clearing and grubbing shall meet department of transportation specifications. 
(i)  Grading shall meet department of transportation specifications. 
(j)  Drainage shall meet department of transportation specifications. 
(k)  The base shall be of top soil or equivalent, and shall meet department of transportation specifications Class "A" or "B". Before surface treatment the base shall have one hundred (100) percent compaction and a one and one-half-inch crown. The base shall have single surface treatment with liquid. 
(l)  The seal shall comply with the following: 
(1)  The prime shall meet all specifications of the department of transportation. 
(2)  Asphalt shall meet all specifications of the department of transportation. 
(3)  Stone #5, 7 and 89 shall be used and meet all specifications of the department of transportation. 
(4)  Triple surface treatment cut back asphalt shall meet all specifications and applications of the department of transportation. 
(5)  Stone #5, 7 and 89 shall be used and meet all specifications of the department of transportation. 
(m)  All side line and center line striping will be completed. The striping requirement shall be the same as the department of transportation. 
(n)  All shoulders and front slopes shall be grassed. Stand requirement shall be the same as the department of transportation. 
(o)  Loose sod shall be placed on side drain pipe in accordance with department of transportation standards and specifications. 
(p)  Ditch checks shall be placed to meet department of transportation standards and specifications. 
(q)  The streets and roads shall be inspected by a qualified person, who will give the board of commissioners a letter stating that all materials, applications, tests and requirements meet the department of transportation specifications. One (1) year of maintenance is required. 
(Mo. of 1-2-74; Mo. of 7-16-02; Res. of 11-11-03) 
Sec. 2-16-2. - Order of paving or tar and gravel of any roads. 
Prior to the paving or tar and gravel of any roads in Lamar County that the order of which they are to be paved or tar and graveled [is] to be set and approved by the board of commissioners. 
(Mo. of 8-15-93) 
Sec. 2-16-3. - Utility locations in rights-of-way. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  As-built plans: Detailed construction plans showing completed improvements as constructed. 
(2)  Utility: All privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems, and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, provider, servicer, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. 
(b)  All utilities locating their facilities in new residential and commercial developments, along county rights-of-way, and along any private road shall locate their lines pursuant to the county's development standards and specifications, as amended. In the event that the county's development standards conflict with the state department of transportation's (D.O.T.) Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards, the County's development standards shall prevail, so long as they are not more restrictive than those of the D.O.T. 
(c)  Upon completion of the installation of its lines and improvements, the utility shall provide the county with as-built plans showing the exact location of the lines and improvements. 
(d)  In the event that the county expands a right-of-way upon which a utility line or improvement has been located, and it is necessary to relocate said line or improvement, in the sole discretion of the county, the utility shall relocate its lines and improvements at its expense. 
(Ord. No. 2017-03, § 1, 8-15-17) 
Sec. 2-16-4. - Utility accommodations in rights-of-way. 
(a)  Adopted. The 2016 Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards manual, including all references contained therein to codes, rules, regulations, schedules, forms and appendix items, except Appendix B (Permit Forms and Supporting Documents), promulgated by the State of Georgia Department of Transportation ("D.O.T."), as amended from time to time, is adopted by reference and incorporated in this section as if fully set forth herein, subject to all amendments and modifications contained in this section. A copy of the manual shall be maintained at the offices of the director of the Lamar County Public Works Department or his designee and open for public inspection. 
(b)  Amendments. The 2016 Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards manual promulgated by the D.O.T., as amended from time to time, adopted in Subsection (a), is amended in order to equate state definitions and provisions with their appropriate and equivalent county counterparts, such that a policy shall be implemented to reflect the intent and effect of the state right-of-way policy as it would logically apply to the unincorporated county's rights-of-way, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Substitutions. 
Commissioner: Lamar County Administrator. 
Department: Lamar County Public Works Department. 
Engineer: The Director of the Lamar County Public Works Department or his/her designee. 
Highway, street or road: Any road that is part of the county road system. 
State: County. 
State bridge and structural design engineer: The Director of the Lamar County Public Works Department or his/her designee. 
State highway (chief) engineer: The Director of the Lamar County Public Works Department or his/her designee. 
State utilities engineer: The Director of the Lamar County Public Works Department or his/her designee. 
Utility (as defined in the state's policy) shall read: 
Utility: All privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems, and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, provider, servicer, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. 
(2)  Administration. The director of the Lamar County Public Works Department shall have the authority to administer the state department of transportation's utility accommodation policy and standards, as amended from time to time by the state or county, on county roads in the unincorporated county and in accordance with any procedures the Board of Commissioners or the Lamar County Public Works Department may establish thereunder. 
(3)  Fees. The board of commissioners shall be authorized to charge fees in accordance with the state department of transportation's utility accommodations policy and standards and any other applicable laws that exist now or may be enacted in the future. Fees shall be determined by the director of the Lamar County Public Works Department and subject to the approval of, and publicly disclosed by, the board of commissioners. Any fee schedule shall be posted at the offices of the Lamar County Public Works Department. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 8-15-17) 
Secs. 2-16-5—2-16-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INTERSTATE SIGNS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 2-5; signs generally, App. B, § 9. 
State Law reference— Signs along interstate highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq. 

Sec. 2-16-23. - Scope. 
This article shall apply to all outdoor advertising signs abutting or visible from the Interstate 75 right-of-way in the county. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § I(1)) 
Sec. 2-16-24. - Compliance. 
(a)  No sign shall be erected or maintained unless it is in compliance with this article. 
(b)  All signs located on sites abutting or visible from the Interstate 75 right-of-way shall conform with Georgia Code Annotated section 32-6-70, et seq. (The Georgia Outdoor Advertising Code) and shall meet all federal and state requirements necessary to obtain a permit from the Georgia Department of Transportation under said code. In instances where the sign controls of this article are more strict, the regulations of this article shall apply. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § I(2), (4)) 
Sec. 2-16-25. - Nonconforming signs. 
Any legally erected sign which would become nonconforming as a result of this article will be allowed to remain until purchased by the state department of transportation provided that the sign meets the requirements of state laws and rules and regulations governing such signs. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(10)) 
Sec. 2-16-26. - Removal of signs. 
Any sign which advertises an activity, business, product or service which has ceased operation or production shall be removed within six (6) months of the discontinuance of said activity, business, product or service. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § I(5)) 
Sec. 2-16-27. - General standards. 
Signs must be constructed of durable materials, maintained in good condition, and not permitted to become dilapidated. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § I(3)) 
Sec. 2-16-28. - Prohibited signs. 
(a)  Signs imitating warning signals are prohibited. No sign shall display lights resembling the flashing lights customarily used in traffic signals or in police, fire, ambulance, or rescue vehicles, nor shall any signs use the words, slogans, dimensional shape or size, of any governmental traffic sign. 
(b)  No signs, except traffic signs and signals and informational signs erected by a public agency, are permitted within any street or highway right-of-way. 
(c)  Signs painted or attached to natural features such as trees or rocks, telephone poles, utility poles, or fence posts are prohibited. 
(d)  Fluttering ribbons and banners are prohibited. 
(e)  Signs within three hundred (300) feet of any officially designated historical site or monument, except signs pertaining to that particular site or monument are prohibited. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § II) 
Sec. 2-16-29. - Home occupation signs. 
One (1) nonilluminated professional or business name plate not exceeding two (2) square feet in area is permitted on the premises of a business. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(1)) 
Sec. 2-16-30. - Signs for work under construction. 
One (1) nonilluminated sign not exceeding forty (40) square feet in area displaying the name of the building, the contractors, the architects, the engineers, the owners, the financial, selling and development agencies are permitted upon the premises of any work under the construction, alteration, or removal. Such signs shall be removed from the site within thirty (30) days after the completion of the project. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(2)) 
Sec. 2-16-31. - Temporary subdivision signs. 
Temporary signs, not exceeding forty (40) square feet in area announcing a land subdivision development, are permitted on the premises of the land subdivision. Such signs shall be spaced not less than three hundred (300) feet apart. They shall be removed when seventy-five (75) percent of the lots are conveyed. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(3)) 
Sec. 2-16-32. - Private directional signs. 
Signs indicating the location and direction of premises available for or in process of development, but not erected upon such premises, and having inscribed thereon the name of the owner, developer, builder, or agent may be erected and maintained, provided: 
(1)  The size of any such sign is not in excess of six (6) square feet, and not in excess of four (4) feet in length; and 
(2)  Not more than one (1) such sign is erected on each five hundred (500) feet of right-of-way frontage. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(4)) 
Sec. 2-16-33. - Roof signs. 
Not more than one (1) roof sign structure (off premises or on premises) may be erected on the roof of any one (1) building. No roof sign structure shall extend more than twenty-five (25) feet above the elevation of the roof. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(5)) 
Sec. 2-16-34. - Wall signs. 
(a)  Signs on the walls of a building (including signs attached flat against the wall, painted wall signs and projected signs) shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The total area of signs on the exterior front surface of a building shall not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the front surface of the building. 
(2)  The total area of signs on a side or rear surface of building shall not exceed fifty (50) percent of the exterior side of the rear surface of the building respectively. 
(3)  Wall signs attached flat against a wall may extend not more than twenty-four (24) inches from the wall. 
(b)  Signs attached at an angle to a wall may extend outward from the wall of a building not more than five (5) feet. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(6)) 
Sec. 2-16-35. - Illuminated signs. 
Illumination devices (on and off premises) shall be so placed and so shielded that light from the sign itself will not be directly cast into any residential district, sleeping rooms in any district or the eyes of an automobile or vehicular driver. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(7)) 
Sec. 2-16-36. - Outdoor advertising signs. 
Outdoor advertising signs shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The outside measurements of all such signs shall be twelve (12) feet in height and fifty (50) feet in length, with or without trim. 
(2)  All illuminated signs shall use base mounted fluorescent or mercury vapor lights and shall be activated by photo-electric cells. Additional lighting including but not limited to neon, animation and running lights is prohibited. 
(3)  All signs shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet above adjacent interstate pavement measuring from the lower portion of the sign face. Signs shall not exceed thirty (30) feet in height. Two (2) signs in the same location (back-to-back) to "V" formation shall be the same height above the interstate's surface. 
(4)  Extrusions beyond the face of the sign, excluding aprons, are prohibited. 
(5)  Only one (1) sign shall be allowed to face the same direction per location. This allows either a back-to-back sign or a "V" formation sign but prohibits two (2) signs (side-by-side) facing the same direction. 
(6)  Sign locations shall be no less than five hundred (500) feet apart measuring from the two (2) closest points. 
(7)  Sign structures shall be no less than ten (10) feet from any property or right-of-way line. 
(8)  Three (3) outdoor advertising signs shall be allowed per quadrant of an interchange adjacent to the Interstate Highway. These signs must be within a commercial or industrial area as specified in state law and are restricted to an area one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet long beginning five hundred (500) feet from the point where the pavement widens on the main traveled way to accommodate the longest entrance or exit ramp. 
(9)  No sign shall be placed in or obstruct the view of a marshland or an area of designated historic interest. 
(10)  Outdoor advertising shall be limited to the following: 
a.  Travel service facilities including lodging, gas, food, camping; 
b.  Areas of scenic beauty; 
c.  Public attractions including historic, natural, scientific or recreational amenities; and 
d.  Any combination of the above-listed facilities. 
Further, the content of all advertising shall be directional in nature. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § III(8)) 
Sec. 2-16-37. - On-premises signs. 
On-premise signs located within one hundred (100) feet of a regularly used part of the activity (building, parking lot) being advertised and located on the same property and "for sale" or "for lease" signs located on the property being advertised are not prohibited. 
(Res. of 3-9-82, § IV(9)) 
Secs. 2-16-38—2-16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ROAD NAME SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— A resolution adopted Aug. 21, 1990, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1—4 as art. III was at the discretion of the editor. The "Base Map—Lamar County" is not printed herein, but is on file in the offices of the county. 
Cross reference— Numbering of properties and buildings, § 2-5-31 et seq. 

Sec. 2-16-51. - Established. 
There is hereby established an official system of road names in the county as shown on the map entitled "Base Map—Lamar County," dated August 21, 1990, as produced by the McIntosh Trail Area planning and development commission. A copy of such map is made a part of this article. 
(Res. of 8-21-90, § 1) 
Sec. 2-16-52. - Changing of names by resolution. 
Names of roads in the county shall remain as shown on the map unless officially changed by resolution. 
(Res. of 8-21-90, § 2) 
Sec. 2-16-53. - Acceptance of roads by county; assignment of names. 
No new roads shall be accepted by the county, and no improvements made therein until such roads have been named. If there are extensions of existing roads, the existing name(s) shall be continued. If not an extension, name(s) recorded may not duplicate or closely approximate road names already assigned. 
(Res. of 8-21-89, § 3) 
Sec. 2-16-54. - Maintenance of system; revisions to base map. 
The county administrator shall be responsible for the maintenance of the system of road names. He/she or his/her designee shall maintain a copy of the map adopted by this article and shall record thereon all changes made by resolution or new assignments accepted by subdivision platting or other legal means. He/she shall cause to be made revisions to the base map to include all official changes made up to the date of revision which is also to be clearly recorded thereon. 
(Res. of 8-21-90, § 4) 
Secs. 2-16-55—2-16-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RIGHTS-OF-WAY USED BY HEAVY EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 2-16-61. - Scope of article and definitions. 
(a)  Scope of article. This article shall cover any industry, trade or commerce that uses a county right-of-way in carrying out its business by loading and unloading materials of any nature whether on the pavement of a county right-of-way or crossing the unpaved portion of the right-of-way including ditches or embankments. 
(b)  Definitions: 
Heavy equipment, machinery and vehicles shall be defined in its everyday meaning. 
Industry, trade or commerce shall mean any commercial activity including but not limited to logging and pulpwood harvesting. 
Loading and unloading shall be defined in its everyday meaning but also shall include any activity known as harvesting or mining of any product or material. 
(Ord. of 1-2-91, § 1) 
Sec. 2-16-62. - Prior to operations. 
(a)  All industrial, logging and pulpwood firms harvesting in Lamar County are hereby required to contact the Lamar County Superintendent of Roads in writing or by telephone and provide the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and phone number of contractor or firm. 
(2)  Approximate location of access site to county road. 
(3)  Approximate date to commence work, cutting and removing said materials or timber, the length of said contract for removing, or the estimated completion date of said operation. 
(b)  Upon notification, the superintendent of roads shall inspect the site to determine if a culvert is required along said county right-of-way and the size and length of culvert if any is required. If it is determined that a culvert is needed, it must be installed by the operator under the supervision of the superintendent of roads. 
(c)  The superintendent of roads shall be authorized to require the posting of a bond in an amount that will recover any repair work. The necessity and amount of the bond shall be in the sole discretion of said superintendent. However, such a bond shall be required only if the potential damage may exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. of 1-2-91, § 2) 
Sec. 2-16-63. - During operations. 
(a)  All industrial, logging or pulpwood loading operations shall be conducted at a loading site off the county rights-of-way and behind the established ditch line of county roads. 
(b)  Loading or skidding of materials, timber or logs will not be permitted on county roads. 
(c)  Ditches shall be kept clear of all debris or residue at all times to allow for proper drainage. 
(d)  County roads at the access site shall be kept serviceable at all times for the passing public, emergency vehicles, school busses and mail carriers. 
(e)  Operators will use crushed stone or some other material, if required by the road superintendent of Lamar County on access roads to prevent the transport of excessive amounts of mud from the operations area onto county roads. 
(Ord. of 1-2-91, § 3) 
Sec. 2-16-64. - Concluding operations. 
(a)  When the Lamar County Superintendent of Roads is advised that the operations have concluded, said superintendent shall inspect the site. If it is determined that the road and access site are not in a proper state of repair due to harvesting operations, said operator shall make the required repairs at his expense. 
(b)  Contractor or operators may remove culverts installed by same upon completion of their operations. 
(c)  Failure to comply with this requirement for repairs will give the county the right to make the repairs and charge the expense therefor to the operator. 
(Ord. of 1-2-91, § 4) 
Sec. 2-16-65. - Violation. 
Any violation of this article shall be punishable as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60. 
(Ord. of 1-2-91, § 5) 
Secs. 2-16-66—2-16-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ROAD USE AND REGULATION 

Sec. 2-16-80. - Purpose. 
This article is made, adopted, and enacted so as to promote the traditional police power goals of health, safety, morals, and the general welfare of the community, the lessening of congestion of county roads and streets, security of the public, promotion of health and general welfare of its citizens, protection of the aesthetic qualities of the county, and facilitation of the adequate provision of transportation and other public requirements; and for the purpose of protecting the county's significant investment in rights-of-way, roads, bridges, infrastructure, and improvements to its road system. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-05) 
Sec. 2-16-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  County shall mean Lamar County, Georgia. 
(2)  County road system shall mean all roads, streets, and roadways owned by the county and operated and maintained for the travel and convenience of the public and shall include all bridges, culverts, ditches, drainage structures, rights-of-way, sidewalks, and appurtenances and improvements to the county roads. 
(3)  Road shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel. 
(4)  Unimproved road system means those roads in the county road system that are not paved. 
(5)  Truck shall mean every motor vehicle with more than six (6) wheels or having an overall length in excess of thirty (30) feet designed, used, or maintained primarily for the transportation or property, goods and material. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-05) 
Sec. 2-16-82. - Route of travel; through trucks. 
(a)  [Through trucks.] All trucks are prohibited from using or parking on any road within the unincorporated area of the county which is posted "No through trucks". 
(b)  Exceptions. This section shall not be interpreted to prohibit the following: 
(1)  The operation of trucks upon any road, when necessary to the conduct of a business, to a destination point; provided roads upon which such truck traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point. 
(2)  The operation of emergency vehicles upon any road in the county. 
(3)  The operation of trucks owned or operated by the county, state, municipality, public utility, public works, or any contractor engaged in the repair, maintenance, or construction of roads, road improvements, or road utilities within the county. 
(4)  The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the road for which such detour is established. 
(c)  The following roads shall be designated and posted for "No through trucks": 
(1)  Johnsonville Road; 
(2)  High Falls Park Road; 
(3)  Brent Road; 
(4)  Fredonia Church Road; 
(5)  Piedmont Road; 
(6)  Five Points Road; 
(7)  Zebulon Road (in Milner); 
(8)  Yatesville Road; 
(9)  Forsyth-Yatesville Road; 
(10)  Old Milner Road; 
(11)  Ramah Church Road; 
(12)  Van Buren Road; 
(13)  Liberty Hill Road; 
(14)  South Sixth Street; 
(15)  Philip Weldon Road; 
(16)  Trice Road; 
(17)  Martin Dairy Road; 
(18)  Chappell Mill Road; 
(19)  High Falls Road. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-05) 
Sec. 2-16-83. - Travel on unimproved roads. 
Trucks shall not travel over any part of the county's unimproved road system during periods of rain or inclement weather when said travel will clearly cause excessive damage and maintenance to the road system such that conditions for the travel of passenger vehicles will be substantially impaired. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-05) 
Sec. 2-16-84. - Travel over bridges. 
Notwithstanding any provision of this article to the contrary, no truck or other vehicle shall be operated over any bridge with a posted weight limit which is less than the total gross weight of the truck or vehicle and its load. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-05) 
Sec. 2-16-85. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any law enforcement agency of Lamar County shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any truck operating on any restricted road to submit to an inspection of said driver's log book, weight slips, delivery slips, or other written evidence of the truck's point or origin and destination point to justify its presence on a prohibited road. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in the Lamar County Magistrate Court, or other court of competent jurisdiction, or upon a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or up to sixty (60) days' confinement in the Lamar County jail. 
(Ord. No. 05-03, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-05) 
Chapter 2-17 - SOLID WASTE AND RECOVERED MATERIALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-17-1. - Solid waste plan. 
The Lamar County Solid Waste Plan as adopted by the Lamar County Commission on September 7, 1993 is incorporated into and made a part of this chapter. 
(Mo. of 6-9-75; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-2. - Littering. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to place, pile, dump or dispose of any trash, garbage or debris of any type on the public roads or on public or private properties in the county except at an approved landfill site. This section does not apply to any person disposing of wastes originating from his own residence on to land and facilities owned by him. 
(b)  This section shall be enforced by the Lamar County Magistrate Court. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or be imprisoned not to exceed sixty (60) days or both. 
(Ord. of 6-9-75) 
Sec. 2-17-3. - Definitions. 
Animal carcass means a deceased animal or portion thereof greater than ten (10) pounds in weight. 
Authority means the Lamar County Regional Solid Waste Management Authority established pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-8-51 et seq., by enabling resolutions of the governing entities of Lamar County and the City of Milner. 
Building and zoning department means the Lamar County Building and Zoning Department, same being the department charged with the day-to-day duty of overseeing the administration of all building, land disturbing, and zoning ordinances assigned to it by the Lamar County Board of Commissioners and the Lamar County Code of Ordinances. 
Bulky waste means appliances, furniture, automobile parts and other materials that exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight or four (4) cubic feet by volume. 
Commercial waste means waste material resulting from commercial operations that differs in weight, bulk, volume or character from domestic waste as defined herein. 
Construction and demolition (C&D) landfill means a facility accepting waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair, or demolition operations on pavements, houses, commercial buildings, and other structures. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, waste containing asbestos, wood, bricks, metal, concrete, wallboard, paper, cardboard, and other nonputrescible wastes associated with construction and demolition activities which have a low potential for ground-water contamination. 
Container means collection container supplied through the authority's solid waste programs, whether supplied by the county, the authority or by a company contracting with the authority to provide solid waste collection services in Lamar County, including without limitation residential curbside collection bins, dumpsters, and recyclable collection bins, containers or trailers. 
Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
Domestic waste means waste, garbage, rubbish and trash such as is ordinarily generated at a residence or light commercial establishment. By way of example, such waste includes but is not limited to waste accumulated from the preparation, processing, consumption, handling, packing, canning, storage and decay of food products, food containers and other consumer goods containers, waste wood, paper, plant, crockery, cloth, glass, packaging material and floor sweeping materials, rags, straw, floor sweepings, and deceased animal matter of less than ten (10) pounds. 
Hazardous waste means any chemical, compound, mixture, substance or article which is designated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate agency of the state to be "hazardous" as that term is defined by or pursuant to federal or state law or regulation. 
Housing. The term housing shall be interpreted to include double wide, dwelling, cluster dwelling, condominium, garden apartment, multiple-family dwelling, patio dwelling, single-family attached, single-family detached, townhouse, two-family dwelling, factory built housing, industrialized home, manufactured home, mobile home, modular homes, multisection home, prefabricated homes, sectional home and single wide; all as defined in section 203 of the Lamar County Zoning Ordinance. 
Incinerator means a furnace for destruction of solid waste by controlled flame combustion. An incinerator must be capable of reducing solid waste to ash. 
Inert waste landfill means a facility of more than one (1) acre accepting only wastes that will not or are not likely to cause production of leachate of environmental concern. Such wastes are limited to earth and earth-like products, concrete, cured asphalt, rock, bricks, yard trimmings, stumps, limbs, and leaves. This definition excludes industrial and demolition waste not specifically listed above. This definition also excludes any site created by a person disposing of organic inert waste (e.g. stumps and other vegetative debris) originating from their own property on to land and facilities owned by said person. 
Materials recovery facility means a solid waste handling facility that provides for the extraction from solid waste of recovered materials. 
Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges, or small quantity generator hazardous wastes, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. 
Recovered materials means those materials which have known use, reuse or recycling potential; can be feasibly used, reused or recycled; and have been diverted or removed from the solid waste stream for sale, use, reuse or recycling, whether or not requiring subsequent separation and processing. 
Recovered materials processing facility means a facility engaged solely in the storage, processing, and resale or reuse of recovered materials. Such term shall not include a solid waste handling facility; provided however, any solid waste generated by such facility shall be subject to all applicable laws and regulations relating to such solid waste. A recovered materials processing facility may also be referred to as a "recycling center." 
Sanitary landfill means an area of land in which solid waste is placed for permanent disposal. The term sanitary landfill shall be interpreted to include inert waste landfills, municipal solid waste landfills, and construction and demolition (C&D) landfills. 
Solid waste means any garbage or refuse; sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, or air pollution control facility; and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining and agricultural operation and from community activities, but does not include recovered materials; solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources subject to permit under 33 U.S.C. § 1342; or source, special nuclear or byproduct material as defined by the Federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923) or hazardous materials as defined under 40 C.F.R. § 261.3. The term solid waste shall be interpreted to include bulky waste, commercial waste, construction debris, domestic waste and yard waste. 
Solid waste handling facility means any facility, the primary purpose of which is the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal, or any combination thereof, of solid waste. This term includes the terms inert waste landfill, municipal solid waste landfill, materials recovery facility, construction and demolition (C&D landfill), incinerator and transfer station, each as defined in this section. 
Transfer station means a facility used to transfer solid waste from one transportation vehicle to another for transportation to a disposal facility or processing operation. 
Yard waste means leaves, tree limbs, weeds, decomposed vegetation and other natural and biodegradable waste such as normally results from clean-up or landscaping of residential or business yards and grounds. 
Zoning administrator means the person designated by the Lamar County Board of Commissioners to administer the Lamar County Zoning Ordinance and their authorized representative. 
(Ord. of 12-7-93; Ord. No. 2008-02, §§ 2—4, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-4. - Scope of authority. 
Lamar County's authority with regards to solid waste management is transferred to the authority to the extent authorized by the authority's enabling resolution, the agreement among participants, and state law. The authority will initiate a curbside domestic waste collection program as set forth herein, will establish facilities for collection of recyclables, will operate and manage the Lamar County landfill, and will perform such other functions as it sees fit within the scope of its authority. Lamar County shall be bound by the contracts of the authority to the extent such contracts are authorized by law and within the scope of the authority's powers under its enabling resolution, agreement among participants and state law. 
(Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Secs. 2-17-5—2-17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COUNTY COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE 

Sec. 2-17-16. - Responsibility for county garbage collection. 
Pursuant to Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 12-8-51 et seq., and the enabling resolution of the Lamar County Regional Solid Waste Management Authority (henceforth "the authority"), the Lamar County Board of Commissioners transfers to the authority the power and responsibility of arranging for the collection and disposal of solid waste, after consultation with the county, which authority shall include but not limited to the following specific powers: 
(1)  The power to establish a program for curbside pickup and disposal of domestic waste as defined herein and to contract for same, including the power to establish curbside pickup and disposal of bulky waste or other waste as defined herein at additional cost to individual consumers of said service; 
(2)  The power to arrange for collection of mandatory fees from each county residence and business for curbside pickup and disposal of domestic waste; 
(3)  The power to establish and operate facilities and sites for the collection and disposal of solid waste and recyclable materials, including but not limited to landfills, dumpsters, recycling containers and recycling centers; 
(4)  The power, concurrently with the Lamar County Board of Commissioners, the Lamar County Sheriff, and the Lamar County Health Department, to enforce by citation or civil action solid waste management programs to the extent they are set forth in this chapter; 
(5)  All other legal powers necessary to effectively carry out the aforesaid tasks. 
(Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-17. - Frequency of collection. 
The Lamar County Regional Solid Waste Management Authority (henceforth "the authority"), within one hundred twenty (120) days of the adoption of this chapter, shall provide for curbside pickup of domestic waste at residences and such other sites as the authority deems fit a least once each week and shall provide common sites where solid waste and recyclable material may be dropped off by individuals and businesses. The authority shall see that the common sites are serviced at regular intervals so as to keep such sites from becoming legal nuisances. 
(Res. of 9-27-74; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-18. - Restrictions on placement of wastes. 
(a)  Domestic waste shall be placed in containers specifically designated for that purpose. 
(b)  No person, business, or other entity shall place hazardous waste, bulky waste, animal carcasses, construction debris or commercial debris, in containers provided for the collection of domestic waste; nor shall any person, business, or other entity place such waste in areas of the landfill unless such area is specifically designated by the authority for those purposes and the person, business or entity complies with rules and regulations set by the authority, including payment of such fees as are set by the authority for placement of same. 
(c)  No person shall knowingly place items that are not recyclable into containers designated for recyclable material. 
(d)  No person shall place waste outside a container. 
(Res. of 9-27-94; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-19. - Use of county landfill and collection sites by commercial and governmental entities. 
(a)  The authority is specifically authorized to contract with private and governmental entities both inside and outside of Lamar County with regards to the disposal of solid waste at the Lamar County landfill, pursuant to such fee rates, payment provisions and rules regarding disposal as are set by the authority. 
(b)  No private or governmental entity is permitted to dispose of solid waste at the landfill, or at any collection site operated by the authority, or in any curbside container provided pursuant to an authority program, without permission of the authority and compliance with authority fee rates, payment provisions and rules regarding disposal. 
(Res. of 9-27-74; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted December 7, 1993, repealed § 2-17-20 which pertained to containers for commercial establishments and derived from a resolution of November 10, 1976 and a motion of November 6, 1990. 
Sec. 2-17-21. - Fires in containers; placing flammable objects in containers. 
No person shall set the contents of a container afire or place highly flammable materials in a container. 
(Res. of 9-27-74) 
Sec. 2-17-22. - Scavenging containers. 
No unauthorized person shall scavenge or remove the contents of a container. 
(Res. of 9-27-74) 
Sec. 2-17-23. - Damaging containers. 
No person shall damage a container. 
(Res. of 9-27-74) 
Sec. 2-17-24. - Service fees; lien for unpaid charges. 
(a)  The fees specified in section 2-17-16, and any other charges, fees, or assessments imposed by the authority, are levied against both the owner and occupant of the premises served, jointly and severally, but collection from one shall relieve the other. These fees shall be collected in the same manner and at such intervals as may be prescribed by resolution of the authority. All uncollected fees due the authority shall constitute a continuing lien against the property served to the same extent, and subject to the same addition of interest and costs, as provided by law with respect to county ad valorem taxes, and may be enforced and collected in the same manner provided for the collection of delinquent taxes, including, but not limited to, the filing of record of a fi. fa. against the property in the Lamar County Superior Court Clerk's Office. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the Lamar County Tax Commissioner to collect the amount of the lien imposed under subsection (a) as if it were a real property ad valorem tax, using all methods available for collecting real property ad valorem tax, including specifically O.C.G.A. title 48, chapter 4; provided, however, that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires twelve (12) months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. 
(Ord. No. 04-02, § 1, 6-22-04) 
Secs. 2-17-25—2-17-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDFILL 

Sec. 2-17-41. - Scope. 
This article III entitled "Landfill" shall only apply to the landfill facility(ies) owned by Lamar County and operated by the authority. The requirements of article V shall not apply to this landfill, to the authority, or to authority facilities. 
(Res. of 9-27-74; Ord. of 12-7-93; Ord. No. 2008-02, § 5, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-42. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted December 7, 1993, repealed § 2-17-42 which pertained to penalty and derived from resolution of September 27, 1974 and October 30, 1994. 
Sec. 2-17-43. - Operating hours. 
The landfill shall be open during such hours as are set by the authority from time to time, which hours are subject to change. The authority shall operate the landfill in such a manner as to adequately serve the needs of county residents and businesses for reasonable access to same. Hours of operation shall be posted in a place accessible to the public; and no person shall enter the landfill when it is not open. 
(Res. of 9-27-74; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-44. - Wastes prohibited. 
(a)  No person, business, or other entity shall place hazardous waste, bulky waste, animal carcasses, construction or commercial debris, in the landfill except in areas and under conditions specifically designated by the authority for those purposes. Each person, business or entity must comply with rules and regulations set by the authority, including payment of such fees as are set by the authority, in placing any such waste in the landfill. 
(b)  No waste that is not acceptable under state and federal environmental laws, rules and regulations shall be placed at the landfill. 
(Res. of 9-27-74; Mo. of 3-26-75; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Sec. 2-17-45. - Fires. 
No person shall set fire to any waste at the landfill. 
(Res. of 9-27-74) 
Sec. 2-17-46. - Scavenging. 
No unauthorized person shall scavenge, sort or remove material from the landfill. 
(Res. of 9-27-74) 
Sec. 2-17-47. - Fees. 
Landfill fees and rates shall be set by the authority and shall change from time to time as the authority deems necessary. 
(Res. of 9-27-74; Mo. of 3-26-75; Mo. of 12-29-88; Ord. of 12-7-93) 
Secs. 2-17-48—2-17-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 2-17-60. - Penalties. 
(a)  Pursuant to Official Code of Georgia Annotated section 36-1-20, violation of any of the provisions of Chapter 2-17, Lamar County's Solid Waste Ordinance, shall be punishable by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), imprisonment for up to sixty (60) days, or both. 
(b)  Jurisdiction over violations of this chapter shall be in Lamar County Magistrate Court. 
(c)  The authority and the county have joint and several rights and authority to file civil lawsuits against persons or entities violating the provisions of Chapter 2-17, to enjoin violations, request equitable relief, or seek damages and costs. Such suits may be filed in any court that would have jurisdiction to entertain them, at the discretion of the filing entity. The right to seek civil remedies is in addition to, and not in lieu of, the right to prosecute citations and seek penalties as set forth herein. 
(d)  The authority is authorized to enforce by ordinance or resolution the collection of taxes, fees, or assessments due to it in the same manner as authorized by law for the enforcement of the collection and payment of state taxes, fees, or assessments as provided in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39.3. 
(Ord. of 12-7-93; Ord. No. 04-02, § 2, 6-22-04) 
Secs. 2-17-61—2-17-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SOLID WASTE HANDLING FACILITIES AND RECOVERED MATERIALS PROCESSING FACILITIES 

Sec. 2-17-70. - Definitions. 
The definitions contained in article I entitled "General" shall apply to the provisions of this article entitled "Solid Waste Handling Facilities and Recovered Materials Processing Facilities". 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-71. - Permit required. 
No person shall operate any solid waste handling facility or recovered materials processing facility within the jurisdictional boundaries of Lamar County without first obtaining a permit approved by the Lamar County Board of Commissioners and issued by the Lamar County Building and Zoning Department. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-72. - Application requirements. 
(a)  Applications for a solid waste handling facility or recovered materials processing facility permit shall be made on forms published and provided by the Lamar County Building and Zoning Department. Permit applications may be initiated upon application by the owner(s) of the subject property or the authorized agent of the owner(s). For the purposes of this section, the term "facility" shall mean a solid waste handling facility or a recovered materials processing facility. 
(b)  Each applicant shall complete all questions contained within the required application form. The applicant shall, under penalty of perjury, certify that all information contained in the permit application and all information submitted in connection with the permit application is true and correct. At a minimum the applicant shall provide all of the following: 
(1)  The mailing address, email address, fax number and phone number of any applicant or agent who is authorized to represent the owner(s) of the subject property; 
(2)  Description: 
a.  A legal description of the property and a copy of any deed vesting title in the owner. This description should include a reference to the deed book and page number or other evidence of title the current property owner may have; 
b.  Location of property by tax map and parcel number; 
c.  Description of any existing rights-of-way, easements, or restrictive covenants affecting the property; 
d.  List of all adjoining property owners giving their name, address, telephone numbers and the zoning classification of their property; 
(3)  A plat of survey of the property, prepared within the last two (2) years and signed and sealed by a land surveyor registered in the state showing the boundary lines of said property and the location of the proposed facility. Said survey shall: 
a.  Indicate the complete boundaries of the subject property and all buildings and structures existing thereon; 
b.  Include a notation as to the total acreage or square footage of the property; 
c.  Delineate the boundaries of the 100-year floodplain; 
d.  Delineate all jurisdictional wetlands by metes and bounds; 
e.  Delineate all streams by metes and bounds; 
(4)  A site plan representing the location of the proposed facility, which shall depict the following information about the property: 
a.  A correct scale, date, north arrow, and legend; 
b.  The owner's name and present zoning classification of all parcels adjacent and across any right-of-way from the property; 
c.  The location of the property relative to existing and proposed streets; 
d.  The location of existing and/or platted streets, easements, buildings, railroads, cemeteries, bridges, sewers, water mains, culverts, wells and gas and electric transmission lines; 
e.  All easements for water lines and sewer lines, both existing and proposed on the property; 
f.  Required setbacks hereunder and for the underlying zoning district; 
g.  Topographic information sufficient to show the elevation and drainage conditions of the property; 
h.  Existing improvements located on the property; 
i.  All buildings and structures proposed to be constructed and their location on the property; 
j.  Height of proposed building(s) on the property; 
k.  Proposed use of each portion of each building on the property; 
l.  The location and extent of required buffer areas on the property, including the extent of natural vegetation or fences as required; 
m.  The proposed location of all driveways and entry/exit points for vehicular traffic for the property, using arrows to depict direction of movement; 
n.  Proposed vehicular traffic circulation patterns within the property and all interior road construction, using arrows to depict direction of movement; 
o.  The location of water bodies, water courses, groundwater aquifers, springs, jurisdictional wetlands and other pertinent water features on the property; 
p.  The location of all test wells and/or borings on the property; 
q.  The location of the 100-year flood plain, and records of flood, including inundation due to dam break on the property; 
r.  The location of historic properties and gravesites, including any plans of relocation of graves and properties having historical significance on the property; 
s.  The location of any archeological sites on the property; 
t.  The location of all threatened or endangered species of state and federal governments and their habitat on the property; 
u.  The location of any cultural facilities such as churches, campgrounds, schools, burial sites on the property; 
v.  The location of any food crop production areas on the property; and 
w.  The location of any commercial plant nurseries on the property; 
(5)  Applicant's erosion and sedimentation control plan and supporting data; 
(6)  An affidavit from an engineer licensed in the state certifying compliance with the requirements of the Lamar County Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance; 
(7)  A letter from the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority verifying whether or not the property has water service with sufficient pressure for the proposed use; 
(8)  A letter from the Lamar County Health Department verifying that the proposed use is not in violation with the health department's applicable rules, regulations and laws; 
(9)  A letter from the zoning administrator verifying compliance with the requirements of the Lamar County Watershed Protection Ordinance and Lamar County Zoning Ordinance; 
(10)  An operation plan showing how applicant plans to operate the facility, including, but not limited to, hours of operation, number of employees, dust reduction measures, traffic control, screening for the dumping of illegal and prohibited waste, and noise reduction measures; 
(11)  A description of the scope of the proposed project, including an estimated schedule of how much and what kinds of waste the facility would accept, where the material would come from, what pretreatment will be required of wastes unacceptable to the facility without such pretreatment, and how long the facility is expected to operate; 
(12)  A traffic plan describing the method of travel to and from the property from each state and federal highway traversing Lamar County; 
(13)  A traffic impact and transportation facilities improvement study, including recommendations for access, road and intersection improvements to minimize adverse traffic impacts; 
(14)  A letter demonstrating access approval from the Georgia Department of Transportation where the facility is to have access on a state road, or from the Lamar County Public Works Department where facility is to have access on a county road or the applicable city where access is on a city street; 
(15)  A copy of all permits issued by and through the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, including, but not limited to, permits issued "by rule." If not yet available, the applicant should provide copies of permits as soon as possible but before issuance of land development or grading permits; 
(16)  A letter signed by all signatories of the Lamar County Regional Solid Waste Management Authority setting forth whether or not the facility is compliance with the joint solid waste management plan; 
(17)  Evidence of liability insurance coverage with minimum limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for sudden events and ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) for nonsudden events.
