Such insurance shall cover injury or damage occurring upon the site of the operation and upon properties in the vicinity of the facility as the result of conditions or activities occurring in connection with the operation of the facility. Such policy shall be filed with the Lamar County Board of Commissioners. The deductible written into the insurance policy shall not exceed five (5) percent of the per-incident limit of the liability of the policy. The coverage obtained by the owner/operator to fulfill the requirements of this section shall include the provision that the insurer shall notify the Lamar County Board of Commissioners thirty (30) calendar days prior to the cancellation of the insurance for any reason. The insured shall provide evidence that ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) liability insurance is to run for five (5) years subsequent to closure to cover postclosure liabilities. Also provide a history of any claims against the applicant, owner or operator at any site, including the record of any subsidiary or parent corporation; 
(18)  A description of emergency procedures and safety and security precautions that will be in use at the facility. This information should include details on emergency assistance and emergency medical treatment that will be required from the area's medical facilities; 
(19)  A phase I environmental impact study, or any study phase greater as required by the zoning administrator after his/her review of the phase I environmental impact study; 
(20)  Documentation showing compliance the site location requirements of [sub]section 2-17-74(a)(8) and the Lamar County Zoning Ordinance; and 
(21)  Any other information that the building and zoning department, zoning administrator, or the board of commissioners may require to properly evaluate the proposed facility. 
(c)  Signed and notarized affidavit of all owners, or in the case of a corporation, partnership or association, all officers, directors, managers or shareholders of five percent or more of stock or financial interest, (hereinafter, "affiant" or "affiants") of the subject property demonstrating the following: 
(1)  Authorization to file the application for a solid waste handling facility or recovered materials processing facility permit, and where applicable, the signed and notarized affidavit of all affiants authorizing an applicant or agent to act on their behalf in the filing of the application for such facility permit; 
(2)  No affiant has intentionally misrepresented or concealed any material fact in the application submitted to the zoning administrator; 
(3)  No affiant has been finally convicted in the state or any federal court of any felony involving moral turpitude within thirty (30) years immediately preceding the application for a permit, excluding those affiants adjudicated pursuant to any applicable first offender Georgia statute; 
(4)  No affiant has been convicted of any violation of any environmental laws punishable as a felony in any state or federal court within thirty (30) years preceding the application for a permit, excluding those affiants adjudicated pursuant to any applicable first offender Georgia statute; and 
(5)  No affiant has been adjudicated in contempt of any court order enforcing any federal environmental laws or any environmental laws of the state within thirty (30) years preceding the application for a permit, excluding those affiants adjudicated pursuant to any applicable first offender Georgia statute. 
(d)  The applicant shall remit application fees as set by the Lamar County Board of Commissioners from time to time so as to reasonably defray the actual cost incurred by the county for review and evaluation of the application; initially, however, the fee shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) until amended. 
(e)  Solid waste generated outside of Lamar County shall not be accepted by any solid waste handling facility for any permitted purpose without the solid waste handling facility property owner(s) and owner(s) of property on which the solid waste handling facility is operated first having executed a fee agreement with Lamar County. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-73. - Application review procedure. 
(a)  Once the completed application, all fees remitted and all documentation as described in section 2-17-72 above has been submitted, the applicant shall provide the zoning administrator with written notice of same. Upon receipt of the applicant's written notice, the zoning administrator shall, within forty-five (45) calendar days, review the application to ensure that all requested information and documentation has been submitted, required fees paid and necessary affidavits have been submitted. Any deficiencies shall be conveyed in writing to the applicant who, after supplementing the application, shall submit a new notice of completeness letter to the zoning administrator. Nothing in this subsection waives the county's right to deny the application due to its insufficiency. 
(b)  Should the applicant fail to obtain any of the required documentation enumerated in section 2-17-72 above, the applicant and/or owner in the case of an agent applicant, shall make all reasonable efforts to obtain the required documentation from the designated authority. 
(c)  Any action by the zoning administrator to approve or deny an application for a solid waste handling facility or recovered materials processing facility permit shall be taken within one hundred eighty (180) calendar days of receipt of a completed application. Any solid waste handling facility permit application for which no action has been taken after one hundred eighty (180) calendar days or more shall be deemed to be approved. 
(d)  The zoning administrator may deny an application that does not comply with any of the provisions of this article, incomplete applications, and applications containing any false material statements by giving written notice to applicant and property owner. Should it be determined that a permit was issued pursuant to an incomplete application or an application containing a false material statement, or that a permit has been erroneously issued in violation of this article, the zoning administrator is authorized to immediately revoke the permit. 
(e)  Should the zoning administrator deny or revoke a permit, the reasons for the denial shall be stated in writing and mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address on the permit application, postmarked on or before the one hundred eightieth (180 th ) calendar day after the zoning administrator's receipt of the complete application, or by hand delivery to the applicant at time of denial. 
(f)  A permit shall not be denied or revoked except for due cause, being the violation of the provisions of this article, other applicable ordinances, state or federal law, or the submission of an incomplete application or an application containing false material statements. 
(g)  Any application denied and later resubmitted shall be deemed to have been submitted on the date of resubmission, not the date of the original submission. 
(h)  Permits are not transferable from one site or facility to another. In accordance with the Georgia Department of Natural Resources rules and regulations, a permit is transferable to a subsequent operator of the permitted facility provided that a new and completed permit application is submitted to the zoning administrator by the proposed permitted, and the proposed permittee agrees to abide by all permitting conditions, agreements and outstanding orders in effect as of the date of the new application or thereafter imposed. Proposed permittees shall likewise comply with all transfer requirements of any applicable state or federal agency. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-74. - Uniform requirements for operation of solid waste handling facilities and recovered materials processing facilities. 
(a)  In addition to the requirements of this article, the zoning Ordinance, Lamar County Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance, joint solid waste management plan, and any other federal, state or local, ordinance, rule or regulation, all solid waste handling facilities and recovered materials processing facilities shall comply with the following requirements of this section. For the purposes of this section, the term "facility" shall mean a solid waste handling facility or a recovered materials processing facility. 
(1)  [Permit.] Applicant shall hold a valid permit from the Georgia Department of Natural Resources and/or U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), if applicable, to operate the facility. 
(2)  [Copies of permits.] The applicant shall provide the zoning administrator with a current copy of all applicable permits from the Georgia Department of Natural Resources upon application for a land disturbance permit. 
(3)  Ingress and egress. 
a.  The main entrance of the facility shall be located on a paved road with a classification of collector or arterial as shown in the street classification system map of the Lamar County Land Use Plan. 
b.  The board of commissioners may consider all traffic impact and transportation facilities improvement studies, including, but not limited to, studies submitted by the applicant pursuant to section 2-17-72, above, and require the applicant to construct or improve a road to accommodate the truck travel necessitated by the operations, as condition of such operation, and for the purpose of minimizing traffic impacts to residential areas. 
c.  The facility shall designate at least one (1) entrance-only driveway separate from at least one (1) exit-only driveway in order to mitigate traffic congestion. All other driveways shall be designed so vehicles will exit the facility in a forward direction. 
d.  Unless otherwise required by the traffic impact and transportation facilities improvement study, a stop sign shall be erected and maintained by the owner/operator at all egress roads from the facility. 
e.  Under no circumstances shall drives or access routes to or from the facility be located within three hundred (300) linear feet of any existing residential driveway or residential subdivision entrance, as measured along the right-of-way line. 
f.  The applicant shall construct an acceleration/deceleration lane for entry into the main entrance of the facility consistent with state and county requirements and standards and post appropriate signage. 
g.  Vehicles using the facility or operating within the facility shall be covered to prevent blowing of material from the vehicle. 
h.  All points of vehicular access to the facility shall be locked and secured after normal business hours by means of a gate or other means of security approved by the building and zoning department. 
(4)  Setback requirements, site barriers, and fencing. 
a.  No such facility shall operate within one hundred fifty (150) feet of adjoining property boundaries and public highways, except for maintenance of said one hundred fifty (150) foot set back area including the required berm, security fence, sight barrier, and animal control. 
b.  A sight barrier shall be provided along all property lines of the site. Sight barrier shall consist of a one-hundred-foot-wide vegetated buffer. Where natural screening conditions of at least three hundred (300) living trees per acre do not exist, the following shall be planted: evergreen trees, not more than ten (10) feet apart in staggered rows. Trees shall be at least two (2) inches in caliper, as measured at breast height, and shall be sufficiently spaced to provide an effective sight barrier when ten (10) feet in height. Trees that die shall be promptly replaced. 
c.  The facility is to be enclosed by an eight-foot high, chain-link security fence with three (3) strands of barbed wire, angled forty-five (45) degrees toward the outside of the premises to the top. The security fence shall be located no less than one hundred (100) feet from the property line, along the inside edge of the sight barrier. 
d.  A planted berm shall be located between the security fence and the facility operations to visually screen the facility operations, but no closer than twenty (20) feet and no farther than fifty (50) feet from the security fence, as measured from the base of the berm. The berm shall consist of the following: a grassed berm six (6) feet in height and planted with evergreen trees not more then ten (10) feet apart, in staggered rows on the berm. Trees shall be at least two (2) inches in caliper, as measured at breast height, and shall be sufficiently spaced to provide effective sight barriers when ten (10) feet in height. Trees that die shall be promptly replaced. 
e.  All entrances shall have an eight-foot-high gate, which shall be closed and locked at all times that the facility is not open. 
(5)  Documentation. Written logs shall be maintained of persons who deposit solid waste or recovered materials into the facility including their name, the date, make, model and license plate of the vehicle, time in and time out, and a description of the material that is being dumped. 
(6)  Hours of operation. Facility hours of operation shall be limited to 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. A sign clearly indicating the hours of operation and prohibiting dumping at all other times shall be placed in a conspicuous location at all entrances. 
(7)  Safety. 
a.  Applicant shall use extreme care and take all available precautions to insure that prohibited waste is not dumped into the facility. 
b.  Suitable means shall be provided at the facility to prevent and control fires. Stockpiled soil is considered to be a satisfactory fire fighting material. 
(8)  Siting: proximity and expansion. 
a.  No portion of a facility shall be located within one thousand (1,000) feet of any of the following pre-existing uses: schools, day cares, churches, hospitals, retirement homes, personal care homes, or subdivisions of record consisting of residential dwellings for which a final plat has been approved and filed with the Lamar County Superior Court Clerk. The distance shall be measured by a straight line from the property boundary of the facility to the property boundary of the aforementioned use. 
b.  Any new facility or expansion of an existing facility shall be located either contiguous to an existing facility, or entirely outside of a ten-mile radius of any existing facility, as measured in a straight line from the property boundaries of the existing facility. 
c.  No portion of a new facility or expansion of any existing facility shall be located within a one-mile radius which contains fifty (50) or more residential dwellings. The one-mile radius shall be measured in a straight line from the boundary of the property to be used for a facility. For purposes of this paragraph, a residential dwelling shall include double wide, dwelling, cluster dwelling, condominium, garden apartment, multiple-family dwelling, patio dwelling, single-family attached, single-family detached, townhouse, two-family dwelling, factory built housing, industrialized home, manufactured home (including class A, B & C), mobile home, modular homes, multisection home, prefabricated homes, sectional home and single wide; all as defined in section 203 of the Lamar County Zoning Ordinance. This paragraph does not apply, however, to a facility to be located contiguous to an existing Facility as provided under subparagraph b. above. 
(9)  Nuisance abatement. 
a.  Air pollution, noise, and vibration, and their effects upon adjacent property owners shall be minimized by the use of adequate soundproofed equipment and buildings designed to accomplish such minimization and approved by the board of commissioners, and by the proper use of berms, walls, and natural planting screens. Interior and adjoining roads used in the operations shall have their surfaces treated to minimize air pollution, noise and vibration. 
b.  Rodent traps shall be placed one hundred (100) yards apart around the perimeter of the facility, inside the security fence, and shall be inspected and cleaned not less than once per day. 
c.  Any security lighting deemed necessary by the owner/operator shall be the sodium-vapor type and shall be aligned so that no part of the illuminated field falls on adjacent property. 
d.  Every facility shall, at its own expense, connect to a public water supply and install at least one (1) outlet every two hundred (200) to four hundred (400) linear feet, as determined by the Lamar County Fire Chief, along the perimeter of the facility's operational area in order to ensure adequate water supply and facilities for quick delivery of water to any part of the property for the purpose of extinguishing fires. Capacity shall be such that at least fifty (50) gallons of water per minute can be applied to any fire, continuously, for at least ten (10) hours. The source of the water supply and facilities to provide for the delivery of the water shall be indicated on the plans submitted for approval to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-75. - Operation standards particular to solid waste handling facility and recovered material processing facility categories. 
(a)  [Compliance with standards, etc.] All federal, state and local statutes, ordinances and rules and regulations, as applicable, shall be met pertaining to the operation of inert landfills, municipal solid waste landfills and construction and demolition (C&D) landfills. Moreover, operations of said landfills shall be consistent with the joint solid waste management plan for Lamar County and the City of Milner. 
(b)  Materials recovery facility (MRF) and recovered materials processing facility standards. 
(1)  All recyclable materials shall be stored in containers with no stockpiling outside the containers. 
(2)  Collection, storage containers, or receptacles shall not be allowed in buffer areas. 
(3)  The sorting, extraction and other processing of recyclable materials shall be done within a fully enclosed building. 
(4)  A maximum continuous sound level of sixty-five (65) dBA and a maximum peak sound level of seventy-five (75) dBA shall not be exceeded at property lines of adjacent property. 
(5)  Collected materials shall not be disposed on or in the property on which the materials recovery facility (MRF) or recovered materials processing facility is located. However, an MRF or recovered materials processing facility may be operated in conjunction with a sanitary landfill. 
(6)  The materials recovery facility or recovered materials processing facility shall be sited and operated in accordance with applicable state and federal statutes, rules and regulations as well as the joint solid waste management plan for Lamar County and the City of Milner. 
(c)  Transfer station standards. 
(1)  Solid waste brought to a transfer station shall not be disposed of on or in the property on which the transfer station is located. However, a transfer station may be operated in conjunction with a sanitary landfill or recovered materials processing facility. 
(2)  Transfer stations shall be sited and operated in accordance with applicable state and federal statutes, rules and regulations as well as the joint solid waste management plan for Lamar County and the City of Milner. 
(d)  Incinerator standards. 
(1)  Solid waste must be burnt for not less than thirty (30) minutes at a temperature sufficient to reduce the solid waste to ash, followed by burial in a sanitary landfill. 
(2)  The operator of the incinerator must date and initial time/temperature records for each batch of solid waste. Said records are to be made available upon request. 
(3)  An incinerator may be operated in conjunction with a sanitary landfill or recovered materials processing facility. 
(4)  Incinerators shall be sited and operated in accordance with applicable state and federal statutes, rules and regulations as well as the joint solid waste management plan for Lamar County and the City of Milner. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-76. - Closure of sanitary landfills. 
(a)  The owner/operator shall comply with all applicable state and federal statutes, rules and regulations pertaining to closure and postclosure. 
(b)  Notice of final closure shall be provided to the zoning administrator within thirty (30) calendar days of receiving the final load of waste. Any site not receiving waste for in excess of one hundred eighty (180) calendar days shall be deemed abandoned and in violation of this article unless properly closed. Notice of closure shall include the date of final waste receipt and an accurate legal description and plat of survey of the boundaries of the sanitary landfill area and property boundaries. 
(c)  Notice that the property has been used as a sanitary landfill shall be filed in the office of the Lamar County Superior Court Clerk within thirty (30) calendar days of closure. Said notice shall include notice that the property was used as a sanitary landfill, the date the sanitary landfill operation commenced and terminated, an accurate legal description and plat of survey of the actual location of the landfill area, and a description of the type of solid wastes which have been deposited in the landfill. Concurrent with the submission of notice of final closure to the zoning administrator, the owner or operator shall submit to the zoning administrator a recorded copy of said notice. 
(d)  All deeds for real property which have been used for sanitary landfilling shall include notice of the sanitary landfill operations, the date the sanitary landfill operation commenced and terminated, an accurate legal description and plat of survey of the actual location of the sanitary landfill disposal area, and a description of the types of solid waste which have been deposited in the landfill. Concurrent with the submission of notice of final closure to the zoning administrator, the owner or operator shall submit to the zoning administrator confirmation that the information required in this section has been noticed on the property deed. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08) 
Sec. 2-17-77. - Appeal. 
(a)  Any appeal of a decision by the building and zoning department, zoning administrator, or other county official regarding this article shall be presented in writing to the board of commissioners within fifteen (15) calendar days of the decision of said county official(s). The appeal shall set forth with particularity the specific violation(s) that occurred, reference all applicable section(s) of this article, any other county ordinance, state or federal law, regulation, etc., give the name of the alleged violator, and provide a statement of the decision being appealed as well as the remedy sought by the appellant. 
(b)  The county administrator shall review the written appeal and schedule a hearing at either a regular or specially called board of commissioners meeting, provided that said hearing is held no sooner than thirty (30) calendar days and no later than sixty (60) calendar days from the date of the filing of the appeal. Notice of the hearing of the appeal shall be provided in the same manner as public hearings are noticed for rezonings initiated by the county under the zoning ordinance. 
(c)  The board shall review the appeal on the basis of the documentation provided as part of the written appeal and any relevant evidence submitted by county staff or the applicant at the public hearing. 
(d)  The laws and regulations of Lamar County, the state and federal governments, and decisions made by county official(s) are presumed to be valid. It shall be the responsibility of an applicant seeking relief to assume the burden of proof and rebut the presumption by presenting clear and convincing evidence to explain how the law, regulation, action or decision is in error and how the applicant's proposed action is consistent with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  It is the duty of the board to review such facts and evidence in light of the provisions of this article to balance the public health, safety and general welfare against the injury to a specific applicant that would result from the strict application of this article to the property. 
(f)  The board may consider whether strict application of this article would create an unnecessary or undue hardship, but only if the hardship is not the result of action taken by the applicant, owner or a previous owner. Any resulting remedy proposed by the board of commissioners shall be the minimum necessary to relieve the applicant of the hardship. 
(g)  After reviewing an appeal filed in accordance with this article, the board may take any of the following actions: 
(1)  Affirm the decision below; 
(2)  Refer the matter back to the decision-maker for reconsideration as to any specific criteria enumerated in this article; 
(3)  Grant the applicant's petition; 
(4)  Grant the applicant's petition with conditions regarding the use of the property, or the facilities, improvements or activities thereon. 
(h)  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the board of commissioners pursuant to this article may appeal to the Superior Court of Lamar County by writ of certiorari as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 6, 7-24-08)

CHAPTER 2-19 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-19-1. - Definitions. 
Authority shall mean the members of the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority, its successors, agents and employees. 
Consumer shall mean any person, corporation, company, partnership, organization (whether for profit or not), association, venture, public body, public agency, public authority, or other entity that uses, has use of, has use for, or seeks to use water furnished by the authority. 
County shall mean the governing body of Lamar County, Georgia, and its successors, agents, and employees. 
Customer shall mean any consumer or developer who desires to receive water services from the authority and who has satisfied the reasonable conditions of the authority to receive said services. 
Developer shall mean any person, corporation, company, partnership, organization (whether for profit or not), association, venture, public body, public agency, public authority, or other entity which purchases or owns property for the purpose of dividing, developing, and reselling at least a portion of the same (whether for residential, commercial, and industrial uses). 
Subdivision shall mean any property divided by a developer for the purpose of developing and reselling at least a portion of the same (whether for residential, commercial, or industrial uses). No property shall meet the definition of the term "subdivision" for the purposes of this chapter unless the same has been properly platted and recorded of record according to the applicable ordinances of Lamar County, Georgia. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. I) 
Sec. 2-19-2. - Access to private property by agents and employees of the authority. 
Duly authorized agents and employees of the authority shall have access at all hours to the property and premises of consumers and developers for the purposes of installing and removing the property of the authority, inspecting the authority's facilities, reading and testing meters, and repairing and maintaining the facilities of the authority. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. II) 
Secs. 2-19-3—2-19-24. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 2-19-25. - Water service where no extension is required. 
(a)  Application. Any consumer or developer desiring to be provided water services by the authority to property owned by that consumer or developer shall make an application for water services in person at the offices of the authority or at such other place as the authority may designate from time to time. The owner (whether consumer or developer) of the property to be served shall be responsible for filling out and providing the authority with a completed application. 
(b)  Water services to consumer with no extension. If the water distribution system: 
(1)  Is adjacent to a consumer's property and no water line extension is required, service will be provided upon the consumer executing the water subscription contract and payment of the connection fees. 
(2)  Is across the road from a consumer's property, service will be provided upon the consumer executing the water subscription contract, receipt of payment from the consumer for the boring, easing and pipe to cross the road, and receipt of payment from the consumer of the connection fees. 
(c)  Water services to developer with no extension. 
(1)  If the water distribution system is adjacent to a developer's property (as described in the vesting deed before subdivision), service will be provided to the nearest property line of the developer's property (as described in the vesting deed before subdivision) so long as the property (as planned for development) has been properly deeded, zoned, subdivided into a platted subdivision and recorded of record as a subdivision (whether commercial, industrial, or residential) according to the laws of the State of Georgia and the ordinances of Lamar County; and so long as the developer has executed a water subscription contract and has paid the applicable connection fees. 
If the water distribution system is directly across the road from a developer's property, service will be provided according to the provisions above, with the addition of the developer paying for the boring, casing and pipe to cross the road. 
(2)  A developer shall, at his, her or its sole cost, extend water lines into each subdivision so that the line will serve each lot developed therein. 
(3)  Any property owner (not otherwise meeting the definition of developer) who purchases a subdivided plot of property from a developer that has extended water lines into a subdivision shall be considered a consumer for the purposes of this section. 
(d)  Waiting list. Once a consumer or developer complies with the above-stated terms, that customer will be placed upon the authority's meter installation waiting list. Thereafter, the authority will install a meter and commence service as soon as is practicable. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. III) 
Sec. 2-19-26. - Water line extensions. 
(a)  Generally. Initially, when public funds are available and a need for expansion arises, in the sole discretion of the authority, the authority will extend water lines throughout the county in the order established by a priority road list adopted by the authority. The priority road list shall be based upon a balance of sound engineering and the goal of expansion of service to most possible consumers and developers. A current road priority list shall be maintained by the authority and made available to the public for inspection. Said priority list may be changed, from time to time without notice, at the sole discretion of the authority. 
During the initial extension of water lines throughout the county and thereafter, extension of water lines at the request of a consumer or developer shall be governed by the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Water service to residential consumers requiring line extensions. 
(1)  Generally. Water lines may be extended along county roads which have a minimum dedicated right-of-way of sixty (60) feet, or along presently existing county roads where easements acceptable to the authority for the installation and maintenance of the water line have been obtained at no expense to the authority. 
(2)  Application. Any residential consumer wishing to have water lines extended to their property shall make an application for water services in person at the offices of the authority or at such other place as the authority may designate from time to time. 
(3)  Application fee. Prior to the commencement of construction, the residential consumer to whose property water lines are to be extended shall pay a sum estimated by the authority per linear foot of water line (of sufficient capacity to service the residential consumer) installed from the authority's existing line to a point perpendicular to the residential consumer's residence (or, in the case of planned but not yet constructed residences, to a point perpendicular to where the residence is planned to be constructed). The estimated sum shall be sufficient to cover all costs associated with design, materials, and construction involved in the extension. Installations over rock and wetlands are impossible to estimate and will be charged at cost. 
i.  In its sole discretion, the authority may establish a program by which the residential consumer may finance the cost of the extension over a set period of time. In such instances, the residential consumer would make regular payments as part of the monthly water billing. 
ii.  In the event that it becomes apparent to the authority that the cost of extension of water lines to a residential consumer exceeds the charged estimate, the authority may immediately terminate work on the extension until such time as the residential consumer pays (or agrees to pay under subsection i. of this section) such additional funds as are necessary. 
iii.  In the event that it becomes impossible, in the authority's sole discretion, to install water lines to a residential consumer, the authority shall refund the application fee provided for in this section. 
(4)  Additional obligations. In addition to all other obligations placed upon a residential consumer by this chapter or other applicable law, prior to the authority approving any residential consumer's application for the extension of water lines and water services, the residential consumer shall: 
a.  Obtain such right-of-way deeds and/or easements as are required by the county and/or the authority; 
b.  Execute the line extension petition provided by the authority; 
c.  Pay the water line extension fees described in subsection (b)(3); 
d.  Pay the applicable connection fee; 
e.  Execute a water subscription contract. 
(5)  Approval by authority. Once the application has been completed, it will be submitted to the authority for approval. If the application is approved by the authority, an estimated date of completion will be given to the residential consumer; however, a date of completion cannot be guaranteed due to changes in work schedule, weather conditions, equipment breakdown, delays in delivery of materials, improvement of right-of-way or other unpredictable circumstances. 
(c)  Water services to residential developers requiring line extensions. 
(1)  Generally. If a water line extension is to serve a developer's residential subdivision development, the developer shall, in addition to obligations set forth in subsection (b) above (regarding residential consumers requiring line extensions), submit to the authority the following: 
a.  An application for line extension; 
b.  Three (3) copies of a plat or accurate drawing of the property to be served. The plat or drawing shall contain the following information: 
i.  Location of the closest existing water line of the authority which is of sufficient size to serve the property; 
ii.  Location of the existing roads and proposed roads to serve the property; 
iii.  An exact footage measurement of water line required to be installed in order to serve the property; 
iv.  Location of all water lines and appurtenances to be constructed in the area to be developed. 
c.  The required water line extension fee. 
(d)  Water services to industrial and commercial developers requiring line extensions. 
(1)  Generally. If a water line extension is to serve a developer's industrial or commercial development, the developer shall, in addition to obligations set forth in subsection (b) above (regarding residential consumers requiring line extensions), submit to the authority the following: 
a.  Line extension application to serve industrial/commercial development; 
b.  A letter from the Lamar County Planning and Zoning Board stating that the property has been properly zoned for the proposed use; 
c.  Three (3) copies of a plat or accurate drawing of the property to be served. The plat or drawing shall contain the following information: 
i.  Location of the closest existing water line of the authority which is of sufficient size to serve the property; 
ii.  Location of the existing roads and proposed roads to serve the property; 
iii.  An exact footage measurement of water line required to be installed in order to serve the property; 
iv.  Location of all water lines and appurtenances to be constructed in the area to be developed; 
v.  Estimated daily consumption. 
d.  The required water line extension fee. 
(2)  Additional lines. if units served will require fire lines and/or sprinkler systems to the structure, expenses for same shall be borne by the developer. 
(e)  Water line services inside residential subdivisions, industrial sites and commercial sites. 
(1)  Generally. It shall be a developer's responsibility to construct and complete water systems inside all residential, industrial, and commercial subdivisions, as well as all industrial and commercial sites. The developer shall: 
a.  Submit the required application to the authority for its approval; 
b.  Pay for all labor and materials necessary to construction of the water line inside the area to be developed, which cost shall include supply lines, fire hydrants, tees, gate valves, reducers and regulators, together with all meter service connection material, including corporation and curb stops, wyes, inserts and service lines to meters, and any other pertinent structure that may be needed for proper construction of said lines and appurtenances thereto; 
c.  Construct all water lines according to plans and specifications of the authority. 
(2)  Additional obligations. Upon completion of the construction of the water lines into the subdivision, but prior to commencement of water services by the authority, a developer shall: 
a.  Execute an affidavit stating the actual cost of all labor and materials expended in the construction of all water lines and appurtenances thereto; 
b.  Execute a deed conveying the water line, appurtenances thereto, and a 20-foot permanent easement to the authority; 
c.  Post a surety bond or letter of credit from a banking institution located within the State of Georgia with the authority in the amount of ten (10) percent of the total cost of construction of said line which said bond or letter of credit shall guarantee payment to the authority for any repairs or maintenance needed in said line over a period of one (1) year from date of conveyance of said line; 
d.  Submit three (3) copies of "as-built" plans of said water lines and appurtenances thereto showing the exact location of the water lines and appurtenances thereto; 
e.  Execute an affidavit prescribed by the authority stating that the cost of all labor and material has been paid in full; 
f.  Pay the required connection fees set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. IV) 
Sec. 2-19-27. - Water subscription contracts required. 
Prior to commencement of water service by the authority each consumer and/or developer wishing to become a customer of the authority must execute a water subscription contract with the authority. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. V) 
Sec. 2-19-28. - Charges for initial water service. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms shall be defined as follows (said definitions shall not limit the meaning of the same terms found elsewhere herein): 
(1)  Construction of water lines. The placing of water lines and the burial thereof in connection with the original line extension project as determined by the authority. 
(2)  Defined service area. The area in which the authority has extended water lines and is currently, or in the future plans to, serve the citizens of Lamar County with water, as that area is defined, from time to time, by said authority. 
(b)  Water connection fees. 
(1)  Consumers. 
a.  For each connection before construction of water lines: 

 
b.  For each connection after construction of water lines: 

 
(2)  Developers. For each connection where developer installs line at no charge to the authority: 

 
(c)  Relocations. Any relocation of waterlines, appurtenances, fire hydrants, or the like requested by the customer or required by the authority will be billed to the customer at the actual cost of the removal or relocation of each of said items. An additional ten-percent fee shall be charged for administrative expenses. 
(d)  Duplexes, quadraplexes, apartments, mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions. A duplex, quadraplex, apartment building, or mobile home park shall have a meter installed for each unit and the prevailing tap-on fee shall be paid for each unit. A master meter may be installed at the owner's request and cost. 
(e)  Professional buildings. A professional building shall have a meter installed for each unit and the prevailing tap-on fee shall be paid for each unit. 
(f)  Security deposits. A fifty dollar ($50.00) security deposit shall be collected for water from all consumers who rent for residential purposes. A one hundred dollar ($100.00) security deposit shall be collected from all consumers who rent for commercial purposes. Security deposits for industrial renters shall be charged on a case-by-case basis. 
(g)  Unpaid bills. Property owners shall be responsible for any unpaid water bills. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. VI) 
Sec. 2-19-29. - Authority's responsibilities and liabilities. 
(a)  Upon a customer meeting all requirements as may be promulgated by the authority, the authority will run a water distribution line to the property of said customer. 
(b)  The authority may, at its sole option, install its meter at or near the property line, or on the customer's property within three (3) feet of the right-of-way. 
(c)  The authority reserves the right to refuse service to any customer whose lines and/or pipings are not installed in such a manner as to prevent cross connections and/or backflow. 
(d)  Under normal conditions a customer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the authority. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. VII) 
Sec. 2-19-30. - Customer's responsibilities and liabilities. 
(a)  Water furnished by the authority shall be used for consumption by the customer, members of his household and employees only, except for customers using master meters as provided in this section, in which case, water furnished by the authority shall be used by those lawfully connected to the master meter only. Customers shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Customers shall not allow anyone else to connect onto the water system serving the customer without the express written consent of the authority. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, or other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Violation of this subsection shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or termination of service. 
(b)  The customer shall have the following additional responsibilities and duties: 
(1)  Where a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a customer, a suitable place shall be provided by the customer therefor, which is unobstructed and accessible at all times to the authority or its designee. 
(2)  The customer shall furnish and maintain a private cutoff valve on the customer's side of the meter. 
(3)  The customer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained at the customer's expense so as to prevent backflow. 
(4)  In order to be received as a customer and entitled to receive water from the authority's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the authority's water system; and all applicants, by becoming customers of the authority, covenant and agree that, so long as they continue to be customers of the authority, they will not permit the connection of any private wells to the authority's water system. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. VIII) 
Sec. 2-19-31. - Turning on or connections to authority's water by persons other than authority personnel. 
Only authorized authority personnel, or such qualified persons as are specifically designated by the authority, can connect or tap on to the authority's water distribution system. No customer, consumer, developer, person, or entity will be authorized to connect or tap on to any water distribution system owned by the authority or on to any water lines carrying water owned by the authority. Violation of this provision of this article shall authorize the authority to immediately terminate water services without notice to the violating customer. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. IX) 
Sec. 2-19-32. - Rate schedules. 
(a)  Generally. All water rates for the customers of the authority shall be set from time to time by the authority without requirement of approval by the county. However, water rates will not increase without ten (10) days notice to the customer. Notice will be sufficiently given to the customer by a publication of the rate changes once in the official newspaper of Lamar County prior to the rate increase. 
(b)  Water rates. 
(1)  The water rates for residential, industrial and commercial customers with a meter of one (1) inch or less shall be as follows: 
a.  For the first one thousand (1,000) gallons used, whether or not any water is used at all, there shall be a minimum charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
b.  For any usage over one thousand (1,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of three dollars thirty-five cents ($3.35) per thousand (1,000) gallons, rounded to the next thousand (1,000). 
(2)  The minimum monthly charge for water meters in excess of one (1) inch in diameter for residential, industrial and commercial customers shall be as follows: 

 
(3)  The fire line monthly minimum rates for industrial and commercial customers shall be as follows: 

 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. X) 
Sec. 2-19-33. - Meter readings. 
The water meter serving a customer's property shall be read on a monthly basis by the authority or its designee and official records of each reading thereof shall be kept for a period of one (1) year. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XI) 
Sec. 2-19-34. - Billing and collection. 
(a)  Generally. The costumer shall pay promptly on a monthly basis for all water registered by the meter serving said property at the rate or rates set by the authority from time to time, which shall include water used and water wasted (including by leakage), except for water that may be traced by the authority to the authority's system. Failure to pay a water bill creates an automatic lien of record in favor of the authority against the property to which the water services are being provided. Said lien may be foreclosed in the same manner as any other lien against real estate as provided by law. 
(b)  Bills. The authority or its designee shall generate and provide each customer with a bill each month for water used. Said bill shall be paid within fifteen (15) days from the date of said bill. In the event that the charges assessed thereon are not paid within twenty (20) days from the date of said bill, the authority shall charge a late fee of one and one-half (1.5) percent interest on the outstanding amount from the twenty-first (21st) day from the date of said bill until water service is terminated, and shall have the right to commence procedures to terminate water services. 
(c)  Bad checks. Customers who make payments with checks that are not covered with sufficient funds in the depository upon which they are drawn shall be charged a "bad check fee" as shall be set by the authority. Initially, the bad check fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). This fee may be amended by resolution of the authority from time to time and any such amendment shall become effective upon publication of notice thereof in the official organ of Lamar County for one (1) week. In its sole discretion, the authority may require any customer whose check has been returned for insufficient funds to pay monthly water bills and all other charges assessed by the authority in cash or certified funds. 
(d)  Resumption of discontinued service. If water service is discontinued for nonpayment, the authority shall not resume water service to the violating customer until the bill and all penalties have been paid in full and a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) nonrefundable service fee has been paid to the authority by the violating customer. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XII) 
Sec. 2-19-35. - Complaints, adjustments. 
(a)  Complaints. 
A.  If a customer believes his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim, in writing, to the authority at the office of the authority before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing termination of service as heretofore provided. The customer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his claim. 
B.  Settlement of claims and adjustments of bills are subject to the following additional provisions: 
(a)  Any consumer who fails to notify the authority in writing within thirty (30) days after the date of a bill of any irregularities or errors that may be in said bill shall waive any right or claim for correction or refund under said bill. 
(b)  The authority will regularly test and replace malfunctioning meters. In addition, water meters will be tested at the request of the customer. If the meter is found to be malfunctioning, no charge will be made. However, if the meter is found not to be malfunctioning, the consumer will be required to pay a service fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) plus the actual cost to the authority for the inspection. Said fee and costs will be added to the next month's billing. 
(c)  If the seal of a meter is broken by any person other than the authority's representative, or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the customer shall pay an amount equal to the average of the three (3) previous months' bills. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XIII) 
Sec. 2-19-36. - Termination of water service for failure to pay bill. 
(a)  Termination of services. The authority shall be empowered to terminate water services for the failure of a customer to pay his water bill. The following procedure shall be followed prior to termination of water service: 
(1)  The following written notice shall be forwarded to the customer and the same shall appear on current billing when said customer has a previous balance: 
"If there is a previous balance (on your account) and it is not paid within 10 days, you are hereby required to appear at a hearing to be held before the Clerk of the Authority at the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority office 15 days from date of this bill (or next working day if this date is a holiday or weekend) at 9:30 a.m. to show cause why your service should not be terminated. You have 10 days from said hearing date to file for injunctive relief in Superior Court of Lamar County; if not, service at this location will be terminated until account is paid in full." 
(2)  The hearing shall be set no earlier than ten (10) days from the date of the notice and not later than fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice. 
(3)  If the customer and the clerk of the authority are unable to resolve any discrepancies that may appear in the bill, the customer shall have ten (10) days from the date of the hearing in which to file for injunctive relief in the Superior Court of Lamar County, Georgia. If no injunction is filed within said time, water service to the customer shall be terminated. 
(4)  If the customer fails to pay the disputed bill or any amount agreed upon by the customer and the clerk of the authority, plus all amounts owed in penalties or late fees, within ten (10) days after the date of the hearing, then said customer's water service shall be terminated. 
(5)  The clerk of the authority, or such other representative as may be appointed by the authority from time to time, is hereby authorized to conduct in behalf of the authority the above-stated hearings. 
(6)  If the customer does not provide access to the meter so that service may be restored, and the authority is required to make an additional service call to restore service, an additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per service call will be assessed and added to the customer's water bill. 
(7)  If service has been discontinued for nonpayment, a customer can re-establish service by paying the total amount due the authority, together with any other applicable service call fees, charges and penalties. Payment must be received in the office of the authority by 12:00 noon on normal business days for same day restoration of service. Service will be restored the following business day for payment received after 12:00 noon. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XIV) 
Sec. 2-19-37. - Suspension of services. 
(a)  Generally. When water service is discontinued, whether by written notice from the customer to the authority or by unilateral act of the authority, the authority shall apply any refundable deposits to the balance of any bill owed by the customer and refund the difference, if any exists, to the customer. 
(b)  Suspension of services. The authority reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following reasons: 
(1)  To prevent fraud or abuse; 
(2)  Customer's willful disregard of the rules of the authority; 
(3)  Emergency repairs; 
(4)  Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the authority's control; 
(5)  Legal processes; 
(6)  Direction of public authorities; 
(7)  Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident, actions of others, or acts of God. The authority reserves the right to terminate the services granted by the authority for any other reason other than those stated above by giving the customer ten (10) days written notice of the date of termination, and further providing the customer with a right to hearing prior to termination of the service. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XV) 
Sec. 2-19-38. - Plans and specifications for construction of water lines. 
The authority shall have the right to specify the requirements, plans and specifications for the construction of water lines in Lamar County. All water lines constructed by any consumer or developer shall be constructed according to the plans and specifications established by the authority for the construction of water lines in Lamar County. No water line shall be covered without first being inspected and approved by the authority. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XVI) 
Sec. 2-19-39. - Cross connection control and backflow prevention. 
(a)  Installation of backflow prevention device required. All customers shall have in place a backflow prevention device of the type, design, and specifications set forth in subsection (c). Purchase, installation and inspection of the backflow prevention device shall be at the expense of the customer, consumer, or developer. 
(b)  Designation as high-, medium-, or low-risk customer; monthly surcharge. 
(1)  The authority is authorized to categorize and designate customers as high-, medium-, or low-risk customers. Said designation shall be made by the backflow prevention program manager, or such other employee or representative of the authority as may be appointed from time to time, based upon his/her evaluation of the customer's property's use and potential for contamination of the public water supply. 
(2)  The authority is authorized to charge each high-risk customer of the system an amount not to exceed two dollars ($2.00) monthly as a surcharge to maintain and administer the cross connection and backflow prevention program. 
(c)  Type of backflow prevention device required; approval of devices. 
(1)  A backflow prevention device shall be of the following types and installed in the following manner: 
a.  Low- and medium-risk customers : The low- or medium-risk customer shall provide a double check valve (DCV) backflow prevention device in a size to match that of the required service meter. 
i.  Specifications. The DCV checks shall have replaceable seats, capture springs and the device assembly shall include a full-port ball valve on the inlet and outlet sides, with a union or swivel coupling nut between the device and each valve. Unions or swivel nuts must be integral with the device or valves. Devices shall have three (3) ball-valve test cocks in the vertical position fitted with brass or plastic threaded plugs. A fourth vertical test cock shall be provided on the upstream side of the inlet shutoff valve. All components of the assembly, including ball valve handles and assembly bolts, shall be equal in corrosion resistance to bronze or stainless steel in order to resist electrolysis. Access to both checking devices shall be by top and/or side entry for maintenance and repair of all interior parts. Valve handles, except T-type, shall turn up to close and in board (ninety (90) degrees) to open. 
ii.  Installation. The DCV backflow prevention device shall not be buried in earth, but models with ready access to both checks may be installed in meter boxes, pits or vaults, provided ball valve test cocks seated with threaded plugs are used. All components of a DCV installed below ground should be resistant to electrolysis. A resilient seat shutoff valve should be near the inlet and outlet side of the device, and three (3) approved test cocks provided on the device. Test cocks below ground shall be chlorinated before use. 
iii.  Sample approved devices : 
Hersey Model # FDC/Unions 
Watts Model # U-007-QT 
b.  High-risk customers. The high-risk customer shall install a reduced pressure zone (RPZ) backflow prevention device. 
i.  Specifications. The RPZ shall be of a size to match that of the required service line or meter. The RPZ assembly shall consist of a pressure differential relief valve located between two (2) positive seating check valves. The relief valve shall function automatically by sensing the pressure differential across the first check valve and discharge the backflow to atmosphere should the check valve become damaged or fouled. The relief and check valves shall have replaceable seats, and the check valves provided with captured springs. A full-port ball valve in sizes through two (2) inches, and resilient-seat OS & Y gate valve in sizes over two (2) inches shall be on the inlet and outlet sides of the device, with a union, swivel coupling nut, or flanges between the device and each valve. Unions and swivel nuts must be integral with the device or valves. The device shall be provided with three (3) ball valve test cocks and a fourth test cock shall be provided on the upstream side of the inlet shut-off valve. Sizes through two (2) inches shall have all test cocks in the vertical position. Test cocks on all assemblies shall be provided with brass or plastic threaded plugs, and relief valve vent-ports shall have suitable connections for an air gap. When a meter or other device with bronze strainer, integral or attached, is not immediately upstream of the backflow preventer, a bronze strainer shall be provided between the inlet shutoff valve and the RPZ on sizes through two (2) inches. All components of the assembly, including ball valve handles and assembly bolts shall be equal in corrosion resistance to stainless steel. Access to both checking devices shall be by top and/or side entry for maintenance and repair. 
ii.  Installation. The RPZ backflow prevention device shall not be buried in earth but shall be installed above ground in a structure that permits positive drainage, has freeze protection, and is located as close as practical to the outlet side of the meter. In lieu of above ground installation, the RPZ may be installed immediately inside the facility provided no intervening connections exist between the meter and the device. Where relief valve discharge could cause water damage, it shall be piped via an air gap at the relief valve vent-port to a floor drain. 
iii.  Sample approved devices. 
Hersey Model Nos. FRP II-U; 6CM; 6CM-RPDA 
Watts Model Nos. U-009-QT; 909OSY; 909DDC. 
(2)  All backflow prevention devices shall be approved by the American National Standards Institute, the American Society of Sanitary Engineering, the American Water Works Association, the University of Southern California Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research, or the Canadian Standards Association. All shutoff valves used with backflow prevention devices shall be resilient seated. 
(d)  Time for compliance; authorization for installation services by the authority. 
(1)  Upon application for new water service from the authority, a consumer or developer shall be categorized as a low-, medium-, or high-risk customer and shall install the designated backflow prevention device required for that category prior to receipt of water services. 
(2)  Existing high-risk customers shall install the designated backflow prevention device within thirty (30) days of the adoption of this section. 
(3)  Existing low- and medium-risk customers shall install the designated backflow prevention device within sixty (60) days of the adoption of this section. 
(4)  The authority is authorized to provide service for the installation of backflow prevention devices in compliance with the standards set out in subsection (c). Installation shall be at the expense of the property owner. 
(e)  Inspection of backflow prevention devices required, maintenance and submission of records by property owner. 
(1)  All backflow prevention devices shall be maintained in proper working order. Reduced pressure zone (RPZ) devices shall be tested immediately after installation and not less than annually thereafter. Double check devices (DCV) in use by low- or medium-risk customers shall be inspected and tested immediately after installation and at not less than five-year intervals following installation. 
(2)  The backflow prevention device shall be tested by a nationally recognized testing laboratory in accordance with the following standards: 
a.  Double check valve device. ASSE standard 1015, and shall bear the ASSE seal. 
b.  RPZ. ASSE standard 1015, and shall bear the ASSE seal. 
c.  [Synthetic components.] Synthetic (i.e. rubber or nylon) components within a backflow prevention device shall be replaced not less than every five (5) years. 
(3)  Each customer and/or owner of property which receives water services from the authority shall maintain a written record of the location, testing, and maintenance of each backflow prevention device on his/her property. Said records shall be provided to the authority upon written request by the backflow prevention program manager. 
(4)  High-risk customers shall submit backflow prevention device inspection and test reports annually to the backflow prevention program manager, or such other employee or representative as may be appointed by the authority from time to time, or more frequently upon written request. Said report shall be submitted within fourteen (14) days of completion of the inspection or written request. 
(5)  The authority is authorized to suspend water service to a customer's premises in the event backflow prevention device inspection and test reports are not provided as required. 
(f)  Entry upon premises for purposes of inspection. The authority shall be authorized to conduct inspections to determine compliance with this section at the discretion of the program manager, or such other employee or representative as may be appointed by the authority from time to time. Agents and employees of the authority shall be authorized to enter the premises of the customer without notice during daylight hours for the purpose of inspection and testing of the backflow prevention device. 
(g)  Installation of thermal expansion device. An auxiliary release valve, or expansion chamber, shall be installed where water is heated and stored in a customer's water system, or a branch of the system, which has been closed by the installation of a backflow prevention device. Said auxiliary release valve or expansion chamber shall be installed to limit thermal expansion of the heated water to not more than eighty (80) psi static (no-flow) pressure at any fixture on the system. 
(h)  Lawn sprinkler or irrigation systems. 
(1)  Lawn sprinkler or other irrigation systems, when connected to the authority's water system, shall include adequate provision for drainage and backflow prevention. 
(2)  Where chemicals, pesticides, fertilizer, or other additives are utilized with a sprinkler system, said system shall have an approved reduced pressure zone (RPZ) backflow prevention device. 
(i)  Penalties for failure to comply with section. 
(1)  In the event a backflow prevention device is found not to be in compliance with those standards set forth in this article, the property owner or customer shall cause said device to be repaired or replaced so as to meet the standards set forth in this section within five (5) days of written notice by the authority. In the event the backflow prevention device is not repaired or replaced within five (5) days after written notice by the authority, the authority is authorized to suspend water service to the property owner or customer's premises without further notice until such time as the device is repaired or replaced such as to be in compliance with this section. 
(2)  Violation of this section by a customer or property owner may be punished by a maximum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per occurrence. 
All existing industrial and commercial customers of the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority shall install at their own expense a backflow prevention valve approved by the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority and all future industrial and commercial customers of the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority shall be required to install at their own expense a backflow prevention valve approved by the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority prior to the commencement of service. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XVII) 
Sec. 2-19-40. - Allocation of water services. 
The authority shall have the right from time to time, if necessary, to allocate water to a customer under specific rules and regulations that may hereinafter be adopted by the authority. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XVIII) 
Sec. 2-19-41. - Amendments to chapter. 
Since special circumstances frequently occur which require changes, amendments or modifications to this chapter, this chapter may be amended without notice upon the approval of said changes, amendments or modifications by the authority and the county. The authority has the right to amend this chapter without approval of the county to set rates and fees and to provide for the construction, operation and maintenance of the Lamar County Water System, generally. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XIX) 
Sec. 2-19-42. - Promulgation of rules and/or policies. 
The authority is authorized to develop, implement, and administer such rules, regulations, and policies as are necessary for the construction, maintenance and operation of the water facilities of Lamar County, including, but not limited to, achieving and maintaining compliance with the rules, regulations and policies of all federal or state agencies having jurisdiction over same. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit any power whatsoever granted to either the county or the authority by that entity's respective legislative grant. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XX) 
Sec. 2-19-43. - Enforcement, generally. 
The authority shall enforce the terms of this chapter through the administrative procedures herein set out or through legal actions in a court of law. The authority shall have the power to issue citations and to call upon the Lamar County Sheriff's Department or any police department created by Lamar County or its successors to enforce the terms of this chapter. 
Any fine which is imposed for violation of any part of this chapter shall be collected by the county and paid from the coffers of the county to the authority for the purpose of mitigating the costs of constructing, operating, and maintaining the water system of Lamar County. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XXI) 
Sec. 2-19-44. - Tampering with authority and county property prohibited; penalties. 
(a)  Generally. All water system facilities shall be considered the property of the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority. Any consumer, developer, customer, person, firm, corporation, company, joint venture, public body, public agency, public authority, or other entity who, without the authorization of the authority: 
(1)  Connects onto a water line of the authority; 
(2)  Disconnects a water line from a water line of the authority; 
(3)  Connects onto a water meter of the authority; 
(4)  Disconnects a water meter of the authority; 
(5)  Moves, removes, changes, or alters the location of a water meter; 
(6)  Changes, alters, or damages any water meter or water line so as to prevent proper registration of water passing through said water meter or line; 
(7)  Obtains water; 
(8)  Prevents any other person from obtaining water; 
(9)  Obstructs or otherwise interferes with the reading or maintenance of any water meter; 
(10)  Obstructs or otherwise interferes with any water line, fire hydrant, pumping station or any appurtenances to water facilities of Lamar County; 
(11)  Creates a hazardous or unsafe condition to the water facilities of Lamar County; 
shall be issued a citation and, if found guilty, shall be subject to a minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to a maximum fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a minimum of thirty (30) days to a maximum of one hundred twenty (120) days. 
(b)  Hearings. The Magistrate Court of Lamar County, Georgia, shall have jurisdiction to hear, try and dispose of citations that are issued for said violations. 
(c)  Citations. Any consumer, developer, customer, person, firm, corporation, company, joint venture, public body, public agency, public authority, or other entity who is charged with having violated this chapter shall be issued a citation by the Lamar County Police Department, Lamar County Sheriff's Department or a representative of the authority. Said citation shall require the appearance of the violator in the Magistrate Court of Lamar County, Georgia, to answer said charges. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XXII) 
Sec. 2-19-45. - Water use restrictions; enforcement. 
(a)  Generally. The authority shall be empowered, in times of drought or otherwise whenever, in the discretion of the authority, such measures are needed, to promulgate restrictions on the use of water by consumers. 
(1)  If a customer uses water in violation of restrictions imposed by the authority, the authority shall be empowered to automatically impose a fine upon said customer which shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per violation. Said fine shall appear on the customer's current billing and shall be delineated separately from water and sewer use billing in such a manner as would be reasonably likely to inform a person of normal intelligence that a fine is being imposed for violation of water use restrictions. 
(2)  If a fine imposed by the authority under this article is disputed by the customer, said customer shall, upon written request within fifteen (15) days of the date of the bill which includes the fine (or the next working day if the fifteenth day is a weekend or legal holiday), be entitled to a hearing before the clerk of the authority, or his or her designee, to attempt to resolve the dispute. Said hearing shall be set on the first available date after receipt of the request, except that three (3) days shall be allowed for sufficient notice of the hearing to the consumer. 
(3)  Notice of the customer's right to hearing shall be included in any bill which imposes a fine and shall read substantially as follows: 
"If you dispute that you have violated Lamar County's Water Use Restrictions, you have the right to request a hearing (in writing), within fifteen (15) days (or next working day if the fifteenth (15 th ) day is a legal holiday or weekend) before the clerk of the Lamar County Water and Sewer Authority, or his or her designee. Your hearing will be set on the first available date after receipt of the request and you will be given at least three (3) days notice thereof. Continuances will be granted for legal cause only." 
(4)  The clerk of the authority, or his or her designee, at the hearing, shall provide the customer (or his or her appointed attorney in fact) with a full and fair opportunity to present relevant facts regarding the alleged violation in the most informal fashion practicable, without regard to the rules of evidence. If, after hearing, the clerk (or duly appointed designee) is unable, based on the facts presented, to remove the fine, the same shall become due and payable and the consumer shall have the right to seek a refund in the Superior Court of Lamar County, by filing a petition therein. 
(b)  Termination of services for failure to pay fine. If a customer fails to pay a fine that is due and payable under this article, the authority shall be empowered to terminate water services to that customer. 
(Ord. of 2-5-02, Art. XXIII) 
Chapter 2-25 - WATERSHED PROTECTION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 2-25-1—2-25-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTLE TOWALIGA RIVER WATERSHED 

Sec. 2-25-19. - Introduction; purpose. 
The Eady Creek Reservoir is located in Lamar County, Georgia, and is owned by the City of Barnesville. The Little Towaliga River watershed is upstream of a supplemental withdrawal at the "Low-Head" Dam on the Little Towaliga River. This withdrawal discharges to the Eady Creek Reservoir. The Eady Creek Watershed upstream of the Eady Creek Reservoir is contained within the Little Towaliga River Watershed. The reservoir is a water supply reservoir for the City of Barnesville, Aldora, Milner and unincorporated portions of Lamar County. The purpose of this watershed protection plan is to establish criteria pursuant to O.C.G.A. 12-2-8 for the protection of drinking water watersheds. This protection is necessary for the enhancement of public health, safety and welfare as well as to assure that surface sources of drinking water are of high quality in order to be treated to meet all state and federal drinking water standards. The criteria set forth accomplish this by establishing buffer zones around streams and by specifying allowable impervious surface densities within the Little Towaliga River watershed upstream of the low head dam intake. 
Secondary objectives are to: 
(a)  Manage the reservoir and the Little Towaliga River watershed in a manner that will conserve the basic resources of air, soil, and water; 
(b)  Provide for diverse and viable plant, animal, and fish communities; 
(c)  Give special consideration for the protection of threatened and endangered plant and animal species; 
(d)  Manage the reservoir to properly establish, enhance, and maintain acceptable fish and wildlife habitat, aesthetic quality, and sustain natural environmental conditions; 
(e)  Manage use of the reservoir in a manner that provides the least environmental impact; 
(f)  Provide for the protection of public land and water. 
(Ord. of 6-21-99, § I) 
Sec. 2-25-20. - Definitions. 
This chapter is made part of and hereby references the Lamar County Zoning Ordinance adopted by the Lamar County Board of Commissioners on October 20, 1992, including section 2101, Sensitive Land-Watershed Protection and is hereby made part of this watershed protection plan. For purposes of this watershed protection plan, certain words or terms used herein are defined as follows: 
Agriculture means the raising of soil crops, poultry, and livestock in a customary manner on tracts of land at least three (3) acres in size, including all related buildings, structures, and appurtenances necessary to carry out all associated activities. Agricultural zoning districts are intended to establish and preserve quiet areas where the primary activities are those of farming, agriculture, livestock, timber cultivation, and related uses consistent with maintaining the land resources of Lamar County. Residences of a low-density nature which are incidental to these activities are also permitted. 
Buffer means a natural or enhanced vegetated area with limited minor land disturbances, such as trails, picnic areas, and land-use practices in accordance with published best management practices such as best management practices for forestry. Buffer setbacks are specified in sections 2-25-23 and 2-25-24. 
Corridor means all land within the buffer areas and other setback areas specified in sections 2-25-23 and 2-25-24 of this plan. 
Impervious surface means a man-made structure or surface which prevents the infiltration of stormwater into the ground below the structure or surface. Examples are buildings, roads, driveways, parking lots, decks, swimming pools, or patios. No impervious surface areas are allowed within the reservoir buffer area as specified in subsection 2-25-23(2)b. 
Land-disturbing activity means any grading, scraping, excavating, or filling of land; clearing of vegetation, and any construction, rebuilding, or alteration of a structure. Land-disturbing activity shall not include activities such as ordinary maintenance and landscaping operations, individual home gardens, yard and grounds upkeep, repairs, additions or minor modifications to a single-family residence, and the cutting of firewood for personal use. 
Perennial stream means a stream which flows throughout the whole year as indicated on a USGS quad map. 
Reservoir boundary means the edge of a water supply reservoir defined by its normal pool level of six hundred fourteen and one-half (614.5) feet above mean sea level for Eady Creek Reservoir. 
Utility means public or private water or sewer piping systems, water or sewer pumping stations, electric power lines, fuel pipelines, telephone lines, roads, driveways, bridges, river/lake access facilities, stormwater systems and railroads or other utilities identified by Lamar County, the City of Milner and the City of Barnesville, Georgia. 
Water supply reservoir means the City of Barnesville-owned impoundment of water (Eady Creek Reservoir) for the primary purpose of providing water to the cities of Barnesville, Milner, and Aldora and Lamar County public drinking water systems. 
Water supply watershed means the drainage area of land upstream of the "Low-Head" Dam water intake, located on the Little Towaliga River at the intersection of Harmony Hill Ranch Road. 
Water supply watershed protection plan is a land use plan prepared and adopted by Lamar County, the City of Milner and the City of Barnesville, Georgia, for the protection of the quality of drinking water obtained from the water supply watershed. 
(Ord. of 6-21-99, § II) 
Sec. 2-25-21. - Coverage area. 
These criteria shall apply to portions of Lamar County located within the Little Towaliga River watershed upstream of the Low-Head Dam intake. These criteria do not apply to watersheds not used for public drinking water supply. 
(Ord. of 6-21-99, § III) 
Sec. 2-25-22. - Exemptions. 
The following activities shall be exempt from the plan.
